story:
I hate Professor Hernandez!
Me too! He keeps calling
text:
I hate Professor Hernandez!
Me too! He keeps calling on us in class randomly and asking questions that are way too difficult. I was completely unprepared during our last lecture and he gave me a low mark on my participation grade. I'm starting to fall behind in his class and it's making me really stressed. 

Have you tried asking him for clarification during office hours or after class to understand the material better? sometimes, teachers are not always clear during lectures, and asking for help can really improve your understanding. Plus, it shows initiative and dedication. 

I know, I've considered it, but every time I try to approach him, he seems too busy or preoccupied with other things. He rarely looks up from his papers or laptop. I don't want to bother him, especially since he seems so distracted. 

Another option you could consider is forming a study group with your classmates. This way, you can all help each other understand the concepts better and prepare for exams. Plus, studying with others can make the learning experience more enjoyable and less stressful.

I hate Professor Hernandez!
Me too! He keeps calling on us in class without giving us enough time to prepare. It's so frustrating. I mean, we're only in our second semester of learning Spanish. We can't be expected to answer every question perfectly. 

I understand your frustration. Learning a new language can be challenging, especially in the beginning. But don't get discouraged. We're making progress, little by little. 

Besides, Professor Hernandez is not trying to frustrate us. He's just trying to help us learn. Maybe we can talk to him about our concerns and ask if we can have more time to prepare for class discussions. That way, we'll be more confident and ready to participate. 

What do you think? 

I believe that's a good idea. It's always better to communicate openly with our teachers if we have any issues. That way, we can work together to find a solution. Plus, we might even learn something new from their perspective. 

So, let's make an appointment to see Professor Hernandez during his office hours and discuss our options.

label: B1
story: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people
text:
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people with a myriad of information and advertising messages every day. It can be overwhelming to keep up with the latest trends and fashion, especially in the fast-paced world we live in. In this context, having effective study skills and efficient note-taking techniques can be invaluable to help us process and retain new information. 

One technique that can enhance note-taking is active listening or reading. Instead of passively receiving information, actively engaging with the text or speaker can help us better understand and remember the content. This can involve taking notes, asking questions, summarizing information in our own words, and relating new ideas to what we already know. 

Moreover, using mnemonic devices, such as acronyms or rhymes, can also aid memory retention. For instance, instead of memorizing a long list of items, one can use an acronym like "ROYGBIV" to remember the colors of the rainbow. 

Another effective technique is repetition, as repeating information can help consolidate it in our memory.

label: A1
story: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people
text:
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people with information about the latest fashion trends every day. But what is a fashion trend? A fashion trend is a popular style of clothing, accessories, makeup, or hairstyle that is widely adopted by people at a particular time. 

Fashion trends change all the time, sometimes quickly and sometimes slowly. For example, a popular fashion trend in the 1960s was the miniskirt, which became very popular and then fell out of fashion, only to become popular again decades later. 

People often follow fashion trends to look stylish and modern. They get inspired by fashion icons, celebrities, and models. But fashion trends are not just about looking good. They can also reflect cultural, social, and economic changes in society. 

Fashion trends are not the same for everyone. They can vary depending on age, gender, lifestyle, and personal taste. For example, a person who enjoys outdoor activities might prefer practical clothing that can withstand the elements, while a person who works in a corporate office might prefer formal clothing that conforms to workplace dress codes.

label: A2
story: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people
text:
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people with information and images about fashion. It's no secret that clothes can make a big difference in how we feel about ourselves. Wearing something new, stylish and trendy can boost our confidence and self-esteem. But what should we do when our budget is limited or we don't have much time to shop? Here are some ideas for making the most of what we have in our wardrobe. 

First, take a good look at what we already own. Often, we have pieces that we've worn a few times but have forgotten about. By rediscovering these items and combining them with something new, we can create a fresh outfit. For example, a simple white t-shirt can be dressed up with a nice cardigan and some jewelry, or worn casually with jeans and sneakers. 

Second, learn to accessorize. A scarf, a belt, a pair of earrings or a statement necklace can transform a plain outfit into something more interesting. Accessories can also add personality and express our individuality. 

Third, invest in basics.

A baby grows up to be a child, then a teenager, and finally, an adult. Throughout this process, a person gains knowledge and experiences that shape their character and personality. 

People communicate with each other using different methods. They can speak face to face, write letters or emails, or use social media. Communication is essential for building relationships and sharing ideas. It can also be a source of entertainment and fun. For instance, people can watch movies, listen to music, or read books. These activities allow us to escape from our daily routines and immerse ourselves in new worlds and stories. 

Traveling is another way to discover new things and expand our horizons. It can be exciting and challenging, but also rewarding. Whether we travel far away or just explore our own city, we have the opportunity to meet new people, taste new foods, and learn about different cultures.

label: A1
story: A baby has arms and legs. It has a mouth and eyes.
text:
A baby has arms and legs. It has a mouth and eyes. The baby can cry and make sounds. It cannot talk yet. The baby needs milk from its mother or from a bottle. The mother holds the baby in her arms and looks at it with love. The baby looks up at her and smiles. 

The baby grows and learns new things every day. It can now reach for toys and grab them. It can roll over and crawl. The baby can make more sounds and begins to understand some words. It can say "mama" and "dada". 

The baby is happy when its mother holds it and plays with it. The mother reads books to the baby and sings songs. The baby listens and looks at the pictures in the books. The baby learns new words and begins to understand simple sentences. 

The baby is growing up and learning new things every day. It is becoming a toddler. The toddler can walk and run. It can say more words and understands many simple sentences. The toddler can point to objects and name them. The toddler is curious and likes to explore the world around it. 

The toddler is happy when its mother plays with it and talks to it.

story: A baby has arms and legs. It has a mouth and eyes.
text:
A baby has arms and legs. It has a mouth and eyes. A baby needs diapers and milk. Babies cry when they are hungry or need a diaper change. People hold babies gently to keep them safe. A baby grows bigger as it eats and sleeps. When a baby smiles, it is happy. When a baby cries, it needs something. A baby can't talk yet, but it understands some words. 

Mom and dad take care of the baby. They feed it, change its diapers, bathe it, and put it to sleep. The baby learns new things every day. It looks around and explores the world with its senses. The baby grows and develops quickly. One day, the baby will be able to walk, talk, and play. But for now, it is content just to be held and loved. 

People say that having a baby is a big responsibility. It takes a lot of time and effort. But the rewards are great. A baby brings so much joy and love into a family. It is a wonderful experience to care for a new life. 

When a baby grows up, it will learn new things and have many adventures. It will make friends and explore the world.

label: B1
story: Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue
text:
Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue of Liberty is "Lady Liberty Enlightening the World." This iconic landmark, located in New York Harbor, symbolizes freedom and democracy. It was a gift from the people of France to the United States in recognition of the alliance between the two countries during the Revolutionary War. 

The statue is a colossal neoclassical sculpture, designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi, and it depicts a robed female figure representing Libertas, the Roman goddess of freedom. In her right hand, she holds a torch to symbolize enlightenment, and in her left, a tablet inscribed with the date of the American Declaration of Independence – July 4, 1776. At the pedestal's base, there are four large bronze statues representing history, courage, labor, and freedom. 

Lady Liberty has welcomed millions of immigrants to the United States over the years, offering them hope and a new beginning. The inscription on the pedestal, "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free" – a passage from the Sonnet "The New Colossus" by Emma Lazarus – further emphasizes the statue's role as a symbol of hope and opportunity

label: A2
story: Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue
text:
Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue of Liberty is "Liberty Enlightening the World." This iconic landmark is located on Liberty Island in New York Harbor. The statue is a gift from the people of France to the United States. It was a symbol of friendship and freedom between the two countries. The statue is made of copper and stands tall at 151 feet. 

On her right hand, Lady Liberty holds a torch with a flame, representing the light of freedom. In her left hand, she holds a tablet with the date of the American Declaration of Independence, July 4, 1776. At her feet, there are broken chains, which symbolize freedom from oppression. 

Visiting the Statue of Liberty is an unforgettable experience. You can take a ferry from Battery Park in Manhattan or Liberty State Park in New Jersey to reach the island. Once there, you can climb up the narrow stairs to the pedestal for a closer look and take some memorable photographs. 

If you want to explore more, you can also visit the museum in the pedestal, which tells the history of the statue and its construction.

label: A1
story: Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue
text:
Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue of Liberty is "Lady Liberty Enlightening the World." It is a symbol of freedom and democracy. The Statue of Liberty is located on Liberty Island in New York Harbor. It's a very famous landmark that attracts many tourists every year. 

The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States. It was completed in 1884. The statue is made of copper and it is 151 feet tall, including its base. On the statue, there is a figure of a woman holding a torch in her right hand and a tablet in her left hand. The tablet has the date of the American Declaration of Independence, 1776, inscribed on it. 

Tourists can take a ferry to Liberty Island to visit the Statue of Liberty. They can climb up the steps to the pedestal or take an elevator to reach the top of the statue. From there, they can enjoy a beautiful view of the New York City skyline and the harbor. 

The Statue of Liberty is an important symbol of the United States. It represents the country's commitment to freedom, democracy, and welcoming immigrants.

story: Karen and Jack had been trying to have a child for
text:
Karen and Jack had been trying to have a child for years, and finally, their hard work paid off. They were thrilled to announce that they were expecting a baby. They shared the happy news with their families and friends, who all congratulated them warmly. 

Karen began to make preparations for the arrival of their child. She read countless parenting books and articles, attended prenatal classes, and bought all the necessary baby items. Jack, on the other hand, helped out in any way he could, from fixing their old nursery to building a changing table. 

As the due date approached, Karen grew increasingly anxious. She went for regular check-ups with her midwife, who assured her that everything was progressing normally. However, she couldn't shake off her nerves. She spent long hours pacing around the house, wondering what being a mother would be like. 

One night, as Jack was helping her with her last-minute preparations, Karen suddenly went into labor. They rushed to the hospital, where Karen gave birth to a beautiful baby girl.

They were once students themselves, and they know that learning a new subject can be challenging. 

I understand that it can be difficult to reach out for help, but believe me, it will be worth it in the end. Don't give up on yourself.

story: I was wondering if I could change my major from biology
text:
I was wondering if I could change my major from biology to psychology. I've been thinking about this decision for quite some time now, and I believe that this change would be beneficial for my future goals. I've always been fascinated by human behavior and the way the mind functions, so switching to psychology seems like a natural choice. 

I've been doing some research about the different fields of psychology and I'm particularly interested in clinical psychology. I'd love to help people overcome their mental health issues and improve their overall wellbeing. However, I'm aware that pursuing a degree in psychology might require more effort and dedication in terms of academic work and practical experience. 

Another thing that excites me about psychology is its versatility. A psychology degree can open up many career opportunities, from working as a therapist to researcher, educator or consultant. Plus, I'm confident that the knowledge and skills I'll acquire during my studies will be invaluable regardless of my chosen career path.

story: Karen and Jack had been trying to have a child for
text:
Karen and Jack had been trying to have a child for a long time. They were very happy when they finally heard the good news from their doctor. Karen was pregnant! 

Karen visited the doctor every month for check-ups. She took vitamins and ate healthy food. Jack helped her with housework and cooked her favorite meals. He wanted to make her as comfortable as possible. 

One day, Karen went into labor. Jack called an ambulance and went with her to the hospital. The doctors and nurses helped Karen give birth to a beautiful baby girl. Jack was filled with joy and held his daughter in his arms. 

They named her Emily. Emily had a head full of beautiful dark hair and sparkling blue eyes. Karen and Jack were overjoyed. They took turns holding Emily and looking at her. 

For the first few days, Karen and Jack stayed in the hospital to make sure everything was okay. They took pictures of Emily and showed them to their friends and family. Everyone was very happy for them. 

Back at home, Jack helped take care of Emily. He changed her diapers and fed her.

story: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people
text:
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people with fashion trends day after day. It is a never-ending process of keeping up with the latest styles and making sure your wardrobe is on point. However, for some, fashion is not only about looking good, but also about expressing their personality and making a statement. 

Fashion is an art form in itself. It has the power to evoke emotions, spark creativity and even influence social change. For instance, during the 1960s, the hippie movement brought about a revolution in fashion. People started wearing long, flowing clothes and bright colors as symbols of peace and love, challenging the mainstream fashion norms of the time. 

Similarly, nowadays, many brands and designers use their creations to promote various social causes. For example, some designers have used their runway shows to raise awareness for mental health issues by incorporating models who openly talk about their experiences with mental health conditions. 

Fashion is not only about clothes, but also about accessories.

label: A2
story: Karen and Jack had been trying to have a child for
text:
Karen and Jack had been trying to have a child for a long time. They visited several doctors, but all tests came back normal. They were worried and confused. One sunny afternoon, they decided to take a walk in the park to clear their minds. 

As they walked along the winding path, they saw a group of children playing on the grass. Karen turned to Jack and said, "I wish we could have a child like that. I'd love to watch them grow up and see all the wonderful things they'll do." 

Jack put his arm around her shoulder and said, "I know it's tough right now, but don't give up hope, Karen. We'll keep trying. Maybe we'll be lucky next time." 

Just then, they heard a loud, joyful laugh. They followed the sound to where a young boy was chasing after a kite. Karen smiled and said, "Look at that little boy. He's having so much fun. I hope we can experience that joy one day." 

Jack nodded in agreement. "We will, Karen. We will," he said, squeezing her hand. Together, they watched the children play and dreamed of the day they'd have a child of their own to love and cherish.

story:

text:
I hate Professor Hernandez!
Me too! He keeps calling on us randomly in class, making us speak in front of everyone without any warning. It's nerve-wracking and not fair. But what's even worse is his unclear and ambiguous explanations of the material. I feel like I'm learning a new language every time I attend his lecture. And don't get me started on his unreasonable homework assignments, they're way too long and time-consuming. It's frustrating that despite all the effort we put into studying, many of us still struggle to keep up with his teaching. 

Moreover, the university administration seems to turn a blind eye to our complaints. They keep insisting that Professor Hernandez is an excellent teacher, but how can someone be excellent if they're making our learning experience so difficult? It's disheartening to see our hard work go to waste due to poor teaching. I wish the university would take our concerns seriously and do something about it. 

Furthermore, the lack of resources and facilities on campus is another issue.

label: B1
story: A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the
text:
A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the ongoing debate about reproductive rights in the United States, calling for the protection of Roe v. Wade, a landmark 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. The senators, led by Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, held a press conference on Capitol Hill to express their concerns over recent restrictions enacted by Republican-led states. 

Warren, a prominent progressive voice in the Senate, was joined by Democratic Senators Tammy Duckworth of Illinois, Patty Murray of Washington, and others. Together, they argued that the right to access safe and legal abortion is essential to women's health and equality. They criticized conservative lawmakers for attempting to restrict access to these services through various legislative measures. 

During the press conference, Duckworth spoke about her own experience of giving birth to her daughter while serving in the military. She noted that women, particularly those in the military, face unique challenges when it comes to accessing healthcare, including access to reproductive services.

Communication between people is essential for living in society. Through language, we can express our thoughts, feelings and ideas. Learning a new language can be a challenging but rewarding experience. At first, it might seem daunting to memorize new vocabulary words and rules for grammar. However, with consistent practice and dedication, one can make significant progress in their language learning journey. 

Immersing oneself in the language and culture is a great way to improve language skills. Watching TV shows, listening to music, and reading books in the target language can help one become more familiar with its nuances and colloquialisms.

label: C2
story:
I hate Professor Hernandez!
Me too! He keeps calling
text:
I hate Professor Hernandez!
Me too! He keeps calling us "lazy students" because we don't understand his complex theories right away. But I firmly believe that his teaching style is antiquated and ineffective. He delivers lengthy monologues in a monotonous tone, rarely pausing to give examples or clarify points. Moreover, he insists on speaking in a jargon-filled language that seems designed to intimidate rather than enlighten. 
It's no wonder that many of us struggle to keep up with him in class. I've tried reading the textbooks and doing additional research, but it's difficult to fully grasp his ideas without his guidance. I believe that Professor Hernandez needs to adapt his teaching methods to cater to the diverse learning styles of his students. Maybe he could try using more visual aids, providing hands-on activities, or encouraging group projects. This would make the material more accessible and engaging for all of us. 
Another issue is that Professor Hernandez rarely provides adequate feedback on our assignments.

story: I was wondering if I could change my major from biology
text:
I was wondering if I could change my major from biology to computer science. I've been taking some computer classes as electives, and I really enjoy programming. However, I'm not sure if I have what it takes to be successful in a computer science program. 

I've been thinking about talking to my academic advisor about this, but I'm feeling a bit nervous. What if they tell me that it's too late to switch now? I'm already halfway through my biology major. 

On the other hand, I've been reading about the job market for computer scientists, and it seems like there are a lot of opportunities out there. Plus, I've heard that computer science pays well. 

I know I'll need to work hard if I decide to switch majors. I'll have to take some prerequisites and maybe even some summer classes to catch up. But I'm willing to put in the effort if it means pursuing something that I'm really passionate about. 

I just need to gather some more information before I make my decision. Maybe I should talk to some current computer science students and find out what their experiences have been like.

label: C1
story: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people
text:
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people with an endless supply of information and advertisements about food. From exotic dishes to the latest superfood, it seems that everywhere we look, someone is trying to convince us that what they are selling is the key to a healthier or more delicious diet. 

However, amidst the cacophony of voices and images, it is essential to separate fact from fiction and to understand the true benefits and risks associated with different foods. For instance, many people believe that processed and packaged foods are inherently unhealthy. While it is true that these types of food can contain high levels of sodium, added sugars, and artificial additives, not all processed foods are created equal. Some processed foods, such as canned fruit or vegetables, can actually be a useful addition to a healthy diet, providing essential nutrients in a convenient form. 

On the other hand, whole, unprocessed foods are often lauded as the pinnacle of healthy eating. However, even these foods can pose risks if consumed in excess.

label: C2
story: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people
text:
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people with endless promotions and enticing offers daily. Amidst this sea of consumerism, it's no wonder that people are constantly seeking the next big thing to satisfy their cravings. However, what many fail to realize is that the most precious and lasting gifts are those that come from the heart and are imbued with thoughtfulness, emotion, and personal touch. 

In today's rushed and materialistic world, the art of giving thoughtful, handmade presents is a rare and treasured commodity. Whether it's a beautifully handwritten letter, a homemade cake, or an intricately knitted scarf, these tokens of affection are often the ones that elicit the strongest emotional responses. They serve as reminders that despite the conveniences of modern life, the human touch still holds immense value. 

Consider the example of a friend who has been going through a tough time. Instead of buying a generic sympathy card or a bouquet of flowers, one could take the time to write a heartfelt letter expressing words of encouragement and support.

label: A1
story: A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the
text:
A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the contentious debate on reproductive rights, calling for stronger protections for women's health and access to healthcare services. The senators held a press conference in the Capitol building to express their concerns over proposed legislation that they say could limit access to safe and legal abortion. 

"Women's rights are under attack," declared Senator Patty Murray of Washington state, a longtime advocate for women's health issues. "We cannot allow politicians to interfere in the most personal and private decisions that women make about their own bodies and their own health. It's a basic human right." 

Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts echoed Murray's sentiments, adding that women should have the freedom to make their own choices about their reproductive health. "This is not a partisan issue. It's a fundamental issue of privacy, autonomy, and equality," she stated. 

The senators urged their colleagues in the Senate to support legislation that would protect access to reproductive health care, including birth control, emergency contraception, and abortion services.

label: B2
story: Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue
text:
Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue of Liberty is "Liberty Enlightening the World". This iconic symbol of freedom has welcomed millions of immigrants to the United States since its dedication in 1886. Standing on Liberty Island in New York Harbor, the statue is a colossal neoclassical sculpture depicting a robed woman holding a torch in her right hand and a tablet in her left, on which is inscribed the date of the American Declaration of Independence. The statue's copper green color is a result of the oxidation process, which protects it from the elements. 

Visiting the Statue of Liberty is an exciting experience. To get there, you must first take a ferry from Battery Park in Lower Manhattan or Liberty State Park in New Jersey. The ferry ride provides stunning views of the Manhattan skyline, Ellis Island, and the statue itself. Once you arrive, you can climb the narrow winding staircase to the pedestal for a close-up view of Lady Liberty. For the more adventurous, you can even climb the 354 steps to the top of the statue for a breathtaking panorama of the harbor and the city.

label: C1
story: A baby has arms and legs. It has a mouth and eyes.
text:
A baby has arms and legs. It has a mouth and eyes. The little one's development is truly astounding. Within the first year, a child can learn to sit, stand, and walk. At this stage, they start to explore their environment, often putting everything in their mouth out of curiosity. They can make various sounds representing different emotions, such as joy, hunger, or tiredness. 

Language development during this period is equally remarkable. By one year old, a child can understand simple commands and follow certain instructions. They begin to form words and create their own babbles. At this point, parents can already notice specific consonant and vowel sounds that their child produces regularly. Moreover, their pronunciation is far from perfect, but they can communicate effectively, making their intentions known. 

As toddlers grow, their vocabulary rapidly expands. By two years old, they can speak around 50 words, and by three, their language skills have progressed significantly. They can now construct sentences with several words and understand simple sentences as well.

label: B1
story: Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days
text:
Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days before the holiday season, hundreds of thousands of federal workers were feeling the pinch. Many of them were facing financial difficulties while some were even considering seeking public assistance. However, in the midst of this turmoil, a group of volunteers had other ideas. 

They called themselves the "Shutdown Heroes" and they decided to band together and lend a helping hand to their fellow citizens. With the closure of many government services, the need was great, particularly for those families who relied on food stamps or other forms of aid. The Shutdown Heroes, made up mainly of local residents and students, began organizing food drives and collection events. 

"We knew that there were people in our communities who were going to be affected by this shutdown, and we wanted to do something about it," explained Maria, a member of the group. They set up collection points throughout the city and reached out to local businesses, organizations, and schools, urging them to donate food and other essentials.

label: A2
story: A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the
text:
A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the heated debate on Capitol Hill on the issue of equal pay for women. The senators, who came from both sides of the aisle, spoke passionately in favor of the Paycheck Fairness Act, a piece of legislation aimed at addressing the gender wage gap and ensuring that women receive equal pay for equal work. 

"Women deserve equal pay for equal work. It's not a radical demand, it's a basic human right," said Senator Jane Smith, a Democrat from the Midwest. She was met with applause and nods from her colleagues. 

Senator Mary Johnson, a Republican from the West Coast, also weighed in. "I am proud to stand with my female colleagues today to support this important legislation. Women in the United States deserve fair and equal compensation for the labor they put into their jobs," she said. 

The Paycheck Fairness Act would update the Equal Pay Act of 1963 by closing loopholes and addressing discrimination based on gender in wage settings. Supporters of the bill argue that it is necessary to address the persistent wage gap between men and women, which sees women earning, on average, only 82 cents for every dollar earned by men.

Karen and Jack had been trying to have a child for years. They had gone through numerous tests and consultations with specialists, but nothing seemed to work. One day, as they were having lunch at their favorite Italian restaurant, Jack's friend Tom suggested they try adoption. 

Karen was taken aback at first, but as Jack explained the idea to her, she began to see the merit in it. They both agreed that starting a family was more important to them than waiting any longer for a miracle to happen.

The baby's parents wait anxiously as the doctor cleans and weighs their newborn. They marvel at the tiny fingers and toes, the perfect shape of the ears. They are filled with love and awe, knowing that this small being is a unique creation, a miracle of life. 

The baby's first few days are filled with constant feeding and diaper changes. The parents' hearts burst with joy as their infant gazes up at them, unaware of the world around him. The first smile, the first coo, the first giggle - these are precious moments that the parents will cherish forever. 

As the baby grows, so does its curiosity. It explores its surroundings, reaching out to touch and feel new textures, tasting new flavors, and listening to new sounds.

label: C1
story: Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue
text:
Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue of Liberty is "Liberty Enlightening the World." This iconic symbol of freedom and democracy has captivated the hearts and minds of millions since its dedication in 1886. Located on Liberty Island in New York Harbor, the statue stands tall and proud, facing out toward the Atlantic Ocean, inviting immigrants and visitors alike to explore the land of opportunity. 

The statue's design is a masterpiece of neoclassical sculpture. Lady Liberty is depicted holding a torch in her right hand, symbolizing enlightenment and progress, while in her left hand, she holds a tablet inscribed with the date of the American Declaration of Independence, 1776. Atop her head sits a crown of seven spikes, representing the seven continents of the world. 

The significance of the Statue of Liberty goes beyond just its aesthetic beauty. It serves as a reminder of the values that the United States holds dear: freedom, equality, and opportunity. Millions of immigrants, many of whom arrived at Ellis Island just a short boat ride away, were welcomed by Lady Liberty and were given the chance to start new lives in this land of promise.

text:
Most people don't know that the full name of the Statue of Liberty is "Liberty Enlightening the World," a title that perfectly encapsulates the statue's significance as a beacon of freedom and enlightenment. Originally a gift from the people of France to the United States, it was designed by French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi, while the pedestal on which it stands was built through a grassroots campaign led by American philanthropist Joseph Pulitzer. 

The statue's iconic image, with its raised torch and tablet inscribed with the date of the American Declaration of Independence, has come to symbolize the hope and promise of a new life for millions of immigrants who have arrived at the shores of New York harbor over the past century. But the Lady Liberty has also become a powerful symbol of freedom and democracy for people around the world. 

Standing at a majestic height of 151 feet, the statue is made of a copper alloy and is covered in a green patina that protects it from the elements. Its intricate details, such as the seven spikes in Lady Liberty's crown that represent the seven continents and the seven seas, and the broken chains at her feet, which symbolize the break from oppression, are a testament to the skill and artistry of the French craftsmen who built her

story: Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days
text:
Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days before the holidays, many federal employees were struggling. They wondered how they would manage without their paychecks. Some were even thinking about finding temporary jobs. The situation was tough, and it seemed there was no end in sight. 

However, not all was bleak. There were stories of kindness and support from the community. Local businesses offered discounts and assistance. Neighbors and friends reached out to help cover bills or groceries. Some organizations provided emergency grants. People came together to help those in need. 

Despite the uncertainty and worry, there was a sense of hope. The community showed resilience and determination, reminding everyone that even in difficult times, we can rely on each other for strength and support. 

Meanwhile, the discussions in Washington continued. Politicians debated and debated, but no agreement was in sight. As the shutdown dragged on, people grew tired and weary, but they held on, knowing that the holidays and the promise of a new year were just around the corner.

label: A2
story: Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days
text:
Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days before the holidays, tension continued to build on both sides. The Democrats and the Republicans remained locked in a stalemate. The Democrats insisted on funding for the border wall, while the Republicans refused to budge on their demand for a spending bill without the funding. 

The impact of the shutdown was beginning to be felt. Thousands of government workers were either working without pay or, furlougged, not working at all. Some had already started to call in sick just to get paid for a few days. Others turned to food banks, while some sold their possessions to get by. In addition, services that Americans rely on daily were starting to be affected: national parks were closed, air travel could become disrupted, and tax refunds were delayed. 

President Trump continued to hold firm. "We need border security," he said in a statement. "The American people deserve a secure border. We will not back down." The Democrats, for their part, refused to give in, arguing that the wall was an unnecessary expense and an affront to American values.

label: B2
story: A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the
text:
A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the heated debate over reproductive rights in the United States, advocating for stronger protections for access to abortion and other reproductive health services. At the heart of the issue is a proposed Texas law, known as SB8, which bans most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy and empowers private citizens to sue anyone who violates it. 

"Every woman in this country deserves the right to make informed decisions about her own body and her own future," said Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, during a press conference on Capitol Hill. "It is unacceptable for politicians to insert themselves into this deeply personal decision, and I will do everything in my power to stop this dangerous law." 

Senator Patty Murray, Chair of the Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee, agreed, stating, "This attack on women's rights is not only unjust, but it's also unconstitutional. We cannot allow politicians to restrict access to essential healthcare services based on their ideology."

The photographs show the Boeing 737-Max, a modern aircraft model produced by Boeing, the American multinational aerospace company. The plane has faced numerous challenges in recent years, especially due to two tragic crashes which occurred in 2018 and 2019 and took hundreds of lives. The crashes were caused by a software bug in the flight control system, Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), that could force the nose of the plane down, leading to dangerous situations for passengers. 

Despite these incidents, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), the American aviation authority, cleared the Boeing 737-Max to fly again in late 2020, after several safety upgrades were made. However, many airlines, especially those based in Europe, are still hesitant to return this plane to their fleets, due to concerns about safety and public perception, which is negatively impacting Boeing's revenue and reputation. 

Furthermore, Boeing's competitors, such as Airbus and European aerospace industries, are taking advantage of the situation to win over customers and gain market share.

story: I was wondering if I could change my major from biology
text:
I was wondering if I could change my major from biology to philosophy for my undergraduate studies. The decision to make such a significant shift in academic direction is not an easy one and requires a great deal of contemplation. On the surface, biology and philosophy seem like polar opposites, but upon closer examination, I believe there is a strong connection between the two fields. 

Biology is the scientific study of living organisms and their interactions with each other and their environments. It is a discipline that has made tremendous progress in understanding the intricacies of life at various levels, from the molecular to the ecosystem level. However, despite the impressive advancements in biology, there are certain fundamental questions related to the nature of life, its origins, and its meaning that are beyond the scope of scientific inquiry. It is here that philosophy comes in, providing a theoretical framework for answering these profound questions. 

Philosophy, on the other hand, is a discipline that deals with fundamental questions about reality, existence, knowledge, values, and ethics.

story: Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days
text:
Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days before the deadline, both parties seem to have dug themselves into an impasse. Democrats and Republicans continue to butt heads over President Trump's demand for border wall funding, leaving hundreds of thousands of government employees out of a paycheck and countless federal services in limbo. 

The impact of the government shutdown stretches far and wide, from air travel to food inspections. For instance, Transportation Security Administration (TSA) employees, who screen passengers at airports, have reported calling in sick in higher numbers than usual due to financial strains. The situation has forced airlines to cancel hundreds of flights in recent days. Furthermore, the shutdown of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has left many food facilities without the necessary inspections, potentially putting consumers at risk. 

Adding to the chaos, there are growing concerns that the situation may lead to long-term economic and political consequences. Economists argue that prolonged shutdowns can weaken business confidence and potentially lead to a slowdown in economic growth.

story: A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the
text:
A bipartisan group of women senators waded into the contentious debate on Capitol Hill regarding gun control legislation last week, advocating for common-sense measures to address gun violence in the United States. Led by Senators Kirsten Gillibrand of New York and Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, the senators unveiled a plan to expand background checks, ban assault weapons, and take other steps to reduce the number of gun-related deaths and injuries. 

Gillibrand, a vocal advocate for gun control, argued that "it is time for us to put politics aside and do what is right for the American people. Our plan is not an attack on the Second Amendment. It is a commonsense approach to protecting the lives of our children and our communities." 

Klobuchar echoed this sentiment, adding, "This is not a radical proposal. It is a responsible step towards ensuring the safety and security of every American." In a fiery speech on the Senate floor, she criticized her Republican colleagues for their unwillingness to compromise and move forward on the issue.

With its compelling storyline, thought-provoking themes, and beautiful writing, it invites you to embark on the journey of a young Andalusian shepherd named Santiago who dares to follow his dreams and seek personal legends. 

As Santiago embarks on his quest, he meets various mystical and enigmatic characters, learns valuable lessons, and ultimately gains self-understanding, realizing that the journey itself is the destination. The book explores the concepts of destiny, personal growth, and the importance of following one's dreams, making it a must-read for anyone looking for inspiration and introspection. 

So, if you find yourself in need of a captivating read that can transport you to another world, I would strongly recommend "The Alchemist" by Paulo Coelho.

text:
Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days before the looming deadline, Congress showed no signs of reaching a compromise on the budget. With the absence of a resolution, thousands of federal workers found themselves in an uncertain situation, unsure of when they would receive their next paycheck. 

The situation was further complicated by the fact that many of these essential workers were required to work during the shutdown, with no guarantee of compensation for their labor. The American public, however, seemed largely indifferent, preoccupied with the upcoming holiday season and their own daily concerns. 

Despite the public's perceived lack of interest, the implications of the shutdown extended far beyond the immediate impact on federal workers. The ripple effects were evident in various sectors, from the economy to national security. 

Small business owners, reliant on federal contracts, found themselves facing cash flow constraints, as the absence of government payments put a strain on their operations.

The image of Alan Kurdi's small, motionless form shook the world and brought global attention to the plight of Syrian refugees seeking safety and a better life in Europe. The crisis that began as a result of the ongoing conflict in Syria has since evolved into a humanitarian issue that has affected millions of people. 

The European Union (EU) has been working tirelessly to provide assistance and to find a solution to this complex issue. EU leaders have implemented several measures aimed at reducing the number of refugees entering Europe through irregular channels and improving the conditions for those seeking asylum. 

One such measure is the EU-Turkey statement, signed in March 2016, which pledged to stem the flow of refugees from Turkey to Greece in exchange for EU funding and other incentives. Under the agreement, every Syrian refugee arriving in Greece would be returned to Turkey, with the exception of those in need of international protection.

text:
Rory McIlroy is off to a good start at the Scottish Open, leading the tournament after the first round with a score of six under par. The Northern Irish golfer birdied five of the last seven holes to take a one-shot advantage over fellow pros Matt Wallace and Marcus Kinhult. 

Playing at The Renaissance Club in North Berwick, Scotland, Rory showed some excellent form, sinking putts and driving the ball long and straight. However, he admitted that the windy conditions made for a challenging first day, and that he would need to remain focused for the remaining rounds. 

Rory's performance was impressive given that he had missed the cut at the previous event, the US Open. His caddie, Harry Diamond, said that Rory had been working hard on his game since then, and that he was looking forward to building on his solid start at the Scottish Open. 

The top three were closely followed by a number of other players, including Tom Lewis, who was just one shot off the lead. With two more rounds to go, the competition is wide open, and Rory will have to maintain his focus and consistency to hold on to the top spot.

story: Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days
text:
Two weeks into the U.S. government shutdown and, days away from the imminent debt ceiling crisis, the political landscape remained as polarized as ever. The opposing parties continued their unyielding stance, each side seemingly unwilling to budge from their demands. The tension in the air was palpable, and the implications for the economy and ordinary citizens were growing increasingly ominous. 

Meanwhile, the World Bank, in its latest report, warned of the potential devastating consequences for the global economy should the situation escalate. The bank's experts projected a significant slowdown in growth, particularly in the United States and Europe, as the ripple effect of the political impasse spread far and wide. 

The White House, however, was unwilling to let the situation go on indefinitely, with reports suggesting that President Johnson was considering invoking the 14th amendment to raise the debt ceiling unilaterally. The move would be controversial, to say the least, with many legal experts questioning its constitutionality.

text:
-LRB- CNN -RRB- More than 22 months ago, the body of George Floyd, an unarmed African American man, was pinned to the ground by a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, who pressed his knee into Floyd's neck for nearly nine minutes. Floyd's agonizing cry for help and subsequent death sparked widespread protests all across the United States and around the world, as people took to the streets to demand an end to police brutality and racial injustice. 

Since then, the movement for social justice has gained significant momentum, leading to numerous reforms and changes. In May of this year, the Minneapolis City Council unanimously voted to abolish the police department and replace it with a new public safety agency. This landmark decision, a response to the community's calls for police reform and accountability, was hailed as a significant victory by activists and observers alike. 

However, the movement for racial justice is far from over. In the wake of George Floyd's death, other high-profile cases of police brutality against Black Americans have brought renewed attention to the issue.

The British tourist who caught a 1-year-old child who had fallen from the balcony of a cruise ship was hailed as a hero. The child, who was traveling with his family on a Mediterranean cruise, slipped from the balcony during a storm. The tourist, who was sitting nearby, quickly reacted and managed to catch the child just before he hit the water. He was later praised by both the child's parents and the cruise ship staff. 

The incident took place on the balcony of the cruise ship's seventh deck, during a severe storm. Witnesses reported that the child had been playing near the railing when he lost his balance and fell. The tourist, who was sitting on a nearby chair, saw the child fall and reacted instantly, diving forward and catching him. 

The parents of the child, who were devastated by the incident, were deeply grateful to the tourist for saving their son's life. They later offered him a reward, but he refused, saying that he was just happy to have been in the right place at the right time. The cruise ship staff also praised the tourist for his quick thinking and bravery.

story: The president she once pointed a gun at has been dead
text:
The president she once pointed a gun at has been dead for many years. The memories of that day still haunt her. she was just a young girl back then, living in a small village at the foot of a mountain range. It was a peaceful place, where people lived in harmony with nature. But one day, an armed rebel group came through the village, looking for the president who was rumored to be hiding there. 

The villagers were terrified. Some of them tried to hide, while others ran in panic. The president's guard managed to escape, but he left the girl behind. She was hiding in her home, trembling with fear, listening to the chaos outside. 

Suddenly, there was a loud banging on her door. It was one of the rebels. She could hear him calling for the president. She knew she had to act fast. She grabbed a small gun that her father had kept for hunting and hid behind the door. 

When the rebel entered, she pointed the gun at him. He was surprised and froze in shock. She could see fear in his eyes. She didn't know what to do next.

story: Just a two-hour detour from Paris, the Loire was once
text:
Just a two-hour detour from Paris, the Loire was once the royal highway, the route taken by the kings of France to travel to their chateaux in the Loire Valley. Today, this area is famous for its beautiful castles and stunning gardens, making it a popular tourist destination. 

I recently had the opportunity to visit the chateau of Chambord, one of the most iconic sites in the valley. With its tall, distinct towers and intricate, Italian-inspired architecture, this magnificent castle was a truly awe-inspiring sight. 

Apart from its stunning exterior, Chambord boasts an impressive history. It was built in the late 15th century by the French king, Francis I, as a hunting lodge. Over the centuries, the chateau has undergone numerous transformations. Some of the most significant work was done during the 17th and 18th centuries. 

The castle is surrounded by vast, sprawling gardens, which offer visitors a chance to wander and explore. The gardens were designed by the famous French landscape architect, Le Nôtre, and include a double-helix staircase, a maze, and a large, man-made lake.

text:
The president she once pointed a gun at has been dead for over two decades, but the memories of that fateful day still haunt her. The sun had just risen, casting a golden glow over the capital city as she made her way to the presidential palace. She had been a devoted supporter of the president, but something had changed within him. Rumors of corruption and power hunger had been spreading like wildfire, and she could no longer ignore the growing unrest among the people. 

As she approached the palace gates, a commotion could be heard coming from within. Soldiers were shouting orders, weapons being loaded, the sound of helicopter blades whirring in the distance. It was clear that something was amiss. Her heart pounding in her chest, she tried to turn back, but the fear of what might happen if she didn't confront the situation head-on was stronger. 

With a deep breath, she entered the palace grounds, pushing through the throngs of terrified civilians and anxious soldiers. The palace itself was a fortress, surrounded by high walls and heavily guarded entrances.

text:
The president she once pointed a gun at has been dead for years. The memories of that day still haunt her. She closes her eyes and tries to recall every detail, every sound. But it's all a blur. She shivers, feeling a cold gust of wind on her back. She opens her eyes and looks around. She's in a dark forest. 

She hears a rustling in the bushes. A twig snaps underfoot. She turns around and sees a figure emerging from the trees. It's a man, tall and muscular. He wears a hoodie and a pair of dark jeans. He walks towards her, his eyes fixed on her. 

She tries to speak but her voice won't come out. Her heart is pounding in her chest. She reaches for her phone in her pocket, but it's not there. She looks around frantically, but it's gone. 

The man stops a few meters away from her. He takes off his hoodie, revealing a scar on his cheek. He speaks in a low voice, "You're coming with me." 

She tries to run, but her legs won't move. He grabs her arms and pulls her towards him. She struggles to get free, but he's too strong.

story: One of the darkest days in American history was September
text:
One of the darkest days in American history was September 11, 2001. It was a day filled with tragedy and shock as terrorists hijacked four planes and used them as weapons, crashing them into the Twin Towers in New York City and the Pentagon in Washington D. C. The third plane, United Airlines Flight 93, was intended to crash into the Capitol Building in Washington D. C., but the passengers, who had learned about the other attacks, fought back against the hijackers before the plane crashed into a field in Pennsylvania. 

The attacks resulted in an outpouring of emotion and support from people all around the world. Thousands of emergency responders, including police officers, firefighters, and medics, rushed to the scene. Sadly, many of them lost their lives as they worked tirelessly to save others. The attack on the Twin Towers caused both towers to collapse, and the destruction of the Pentagon left a large hole in the side of the building. 

The United States government responded to the attacks by declaring a War on Terror and launching military actions against the group responsible, al-Qaeda.

story: Halloween is on October 31. It is also called All Hallows'
text:
Halloween is on October 31. It is also called All Hallows' Eve or All Saints' Eve. This ancient traditional festival originated with the Celts in England around 2000 years ago. They believed that on this night, the boundary between the worlds of the living and the dead became blurred and the ghosts of the dead returned to earth. 

To celebrate Halloween, people often wear costumes and masks, go house to house asking for sweets or small gifts with the phrase "Trick or Treat." There are also various games and activities associated with Halloween, such as carving pumpkins into lanterns, apple bobbing, and telling scary stories. 

One popular Halloween tradition is making and eating jack-o'-lanterns, which are carved pumpkins with a lighted candle inside. The name jack-o'-lantern comes from an old Irish legend about a man named Stingy Jack, who could not be allowed to enter either heaven or hell after his death. Jack was given an eternally burning lantern to roam the earth with. 

Another fun activity is baking delicious treats for Halloween.

Apart from historical treasures, the Loire Valley is also famous for its vineyards, producing some of the finest French wines. The region is particularly well-known for its white wines made from Chenin Blanc grapes and its red wines from Cabernet Franc.

These impacts caused immense destruction, with towers engulfed in fires and smoke. Thousands of people were trapped inside, many of whom perished due to the collapse of the towers at 9:59 am and 10:28 am respectively. 

Simultaneously, American Airlines Flight 77 was hijacked and deliberately crashed into the Pentagon at 9:37 am, resulting in significant damage to the building and the death of over fifty individuals.

text:
Report on staff engagement at Girox Foods
Introduction
At Girox Foods, an international food manufacturing company, we believe that the engagement and motivation of our staff is essential for the success of our business. A highly engaged workforce leads to increased productivity, lower turnover rates, and improved customer satisfaction. In this report, we will analyze the current level of staff engagement at our facility in Barcelona, Spain, and propose recommendations for addressing areas for improvement. 

Findings
Our recent staff engagement survey indicated that while the majority of employees (63%) feel engaged or very engaged with their work, there are still some areas for concern. For instance, 24% of respondents reported that they feel neutral or not engaged, and 13% stated that they feel disengaged (see Figure 1). 

Further analysis revealed that several factors contribute to lower engagement levels. These include:

1. Lack of clear communication from management: Some employees feel that they are not kept informed about the company's goals, strategies, and performance.

story: Halloween is on October 31. It is also called All Hallows'
text:
Halloween is on October 31. It is also called All Hallows' Eve, which comes from the ancient Celtic festival of Samhain. This night was believed to be when the boundary between the worlds of the living and the dead became blurred. During this time, people would wear costumes to disguise themselves from the roaming spirits. Today, children dress up in costumes and go door to door to ask for candy. 

People can make their own costumes at home or buy them at stores. There are many creative options, such as transforming themselves into superheroes, animals, or even famous characters. Some people even create elaborate and intricate costumes for Halloween parties. 

Halloween is not only celebrated in the United States, but also in many other countries. For example, in Mexico, it is known as El Día de las Calaveras, or the Day of the Skulls. The tradition is to create brightly painted calaveras, or skulls, out of sugar or chocolate. These skulls represent the dead and are meant to celebrate and honor them. 

Halloween is a fun and exciting time of the year, full of creativity, tradition, and celebration.

They believe that their spirits come back to visit during this day. They decorate the altar with flowers, candles and pictures of the dead people. They also cook their favorite food for them. 

In the United States, Canada and United Kingdom, some people have a party on Halloween. They decorate their houses with ghosts and witches. Some people also play pranks on their neighbors. This can be a fun night for children and adults. 

However, not everyone celebrates this day. In some countries, like China or Greece, people do not celebrate Halloween. They have different traditions and celebrations for the dead. 

Overall, Halloween is a fun day for many people.

story: Halloween is on October 31. It is also called All Hallows'
text:
Halloween is on October 31. It is also called All Hallows' Eve. This ancient Celtic festival has been celebrated for over 2,000 years, mainly in Europe and North America. The Celts believed that on this night, the boundary between the worlds of the living and the dead became blurred and the ghosts of the dead returned to earth. 

To celebrate Halloween, people wear costumes and go from house to house, asking for sweets with the phrase "Trick or treat!" Those who don't want to give out treats might find a trick played on them instead. Jack-o'-lanterns, carved from turnips or pumpkins, are also a common symbol of Halloween. Their origins go back to an Irish legend of a man named Jack who was denied entry into both heaven and hell. Wandering the earth, he met a lady whose soul he helped to keep from an evil creature, and she placed a glowing coal in a hollowed-out turnip for him to carry. This has led to the tradition of carving lanterns from root vegetables, often with scary faces. 

Halloween parties are popular, and children and adults alike enjoy games, such as apple bobbing and snap apple.

If your application is approved, you will be placed on a waiting list and notified when a unit becomes available that matches your needs and eligibility. Once you are offered a unit, you must act quickly to secure it, as other applicants may also be considering the same unit. 

It is important to remember that the process of applying for public housing can be competitive, and the demand for units often exceeds the supply.

The teams were ready. They all held their paintball guns and looked determined. The sun was shining, and the wind was light.

label: B1
story: Nowadays all the information we could ever need is
text:
Nowadays all the information we could ever need is available at our fingertips. However, with so much data at our disposal, it's essential to know how to find what we're looking for efficiently. This is where good research skills come in handy. 

First, let's define what research means. Research is the process of investigating a particular topic to find answers to specific questions. It involves gathering, interpreting, and analyzing information from various sources. This skill is crucial in both our personal and professional lives, as it helps us make informed decisions, gain knowledge, and solve problems. 

To conduct effective research, follow these steps:

1. Define your research question: Before you start your search, be clear about what you want to find out. A good research question is specific, clear, and answerable. For instance, instead of asking "What is the best diet for weight loss? ", ask a more specific question like "What are the benefits and drawbacks of a low-carb vs. low-fat diet for weight loss?"

label: B2
story: When you apply for public housing, on the application
text:
When you apply for public housing, on the application form there are usually several questions related to your financial situation. It is important to provide accurate and up-to-date information, as the housing authorities will use this information to determine your eligibility for the program. Here are some common financial questions you may encounter:

1. Income: You will be asked to report your total monthly income from all sources. This can include wages, unemployment benefits, pensions, alimony or child support, and any other forms of regular income. Be sure to include the gross amount before any deductions or taxes are taken out. 

2. Assets: You may also be asked about your assets, such as bank account balances, stocks, bonds, and real estate property. The housing authority may have a certain asset limit, above which you will not be eligible for public housing. 

3. Expenses: You will be asked to report your ongoing monthly expenses, such as rent or mortgage payments, utilities, food, transportation, and healthcare costs.

story: When you apply for public housing, on the application
text:
When you apply for public housing, on the application form, you will be asked to provide some personal information. You'll need to write down your full name, your address, your contact details, and maybe your date of birth. It's important to be precise and provide accurate information. 

Next, you'll need to explain why you need public housing. You can write something like, "I'm having financial difficulties and cannot afford to pay for housing on my own." Or, "I've lost my job and have no income." Be sure to explain your situation clearly and honestly. 

The application may ask you for proof of income, such as your recent bank statements or payslips. Make sure you have these documents ready before you apply. It's also important to note that some public housing programs have income limits, so check to see if your income falls within those limits. 

Lastly, you'll need to provide proof of identity. This can be a driver's license, a passport, or a government-issued ID card. Again, make sure the document is valid and that you have a clear copy of it.

Moreover, in countries with a chronic housing shortage, the waiting list for public housing can extend for years or even decades. 

In such a context, it is important to thoroughly research the specific rules and regulations in the location where you intend to apply for public housing. You can consult with local authorities, community organizations, and social services to gather accurate and up-to-date information. 

Additionally, you may find it helpful to seek advice from an immigration lawyer or a legal aid organization, especially if you plan to apply for public housing in a foreign country.

She made a mental note to research renewable energy sources for her next project.

label: A1
story: Johnny Carson served as host for the iconic, late-night
text:
Johnny Carson served as host for the iconic, late-night television program, The Tonight Show, from 1962 to 1992. This show was a staple for many Americans and offered an enjoyable mix of comedy, interviews, and entertainment. 

Johnny Carson was born on October 23, 1925, in Corning, Iowa, and grew up in Nebraska. He began his career in show business in the early 1940s as a disc jockey. He also appeared in vaudeville acts and later on radio broadcasts. In the 1950s and 1960s, he worked on numerous television programs. 

In 1962, Johnny Carson took over as the host of The Tonight Show. His quick wit, humor, and ability to connect with guests and audiences made the show a success. The format of the show included monologues, comedy sketches, games, interviews, and musical performances. 

One popular segment featured on The Tonight Show was the "Carnac the Magnificent" character. Carnac the Magnificent was portrayed as a fortune-teller with psychic abilities. He would wear a turban, a cape, and a crystal ball, and predict the answers to various questions, often in humorous ways.

label: B1
story: A proposal for a digital version of the university
text:
A proposal for a digital version of the university library: With the rapid advancement of technology, the traditional library is evolving, and a digital library is becoming more and more popular. Students and faculty now have the opportunity to access vast amounts of information from anywhere at any time. In this context, our university library should consider implementing a digital version to provide more convenience and efficiency for its users. 

Firstly, a digital library would grant students and faculty the ability to access resources anytime and anywhere they want. Gone are the days where students have to physically go to the library, wait for someone to fetch the book they need, or even worse, finding out that the book they need is not available. With a digital library, they can simply log in from their computers or mobile devices and have instant access to a vast collection of academic resources. 

Secondly, a digital library offers the advantage of being able to search for specific information more easily and quickly.

label: C2
story: Helen turned on her flashlight. Nothing happened. The
text:
Helen turned on her flashlight. Nothing happened. The power outage had been going on for hours, leaving her in complete darkness in her cozy apartment. It was an unusually stormy night and the heavy rain outside added to the sense of unease she felt. She checked her mobile phone, which was still charged, and called the electricity company's emergency line. After being put on hold for what seemed like an eternity, she was informed that they were aware of the issue and were working on it as quickly as possible. 

Despite the assurance, Helen couldn't shake off the feeling of frustration. She relied heavily on electricity for her work and the thought of losing a day's productivity due to a power outage was enough to make her anxious. In the meantime, she could only wait and try to make the most of the situation. 

She rummaged through her cupboards, searching for candles and matches. With the rain pouring outside, the only sound to be heard was the occasional crack of thunder. Helen took out a book she had been meaning to read for a long time.

label: A2
story: Helen turned on her flashlight. Nothing happened. The
text:
Helen turned on her flashlight. Nothing happened. The small room was shrouded in darkness. She felt a cold sweat break out on her forehead. How could she have forgotten the batteries for her flashlight? She took a deep breath and tried to calm herself. She couldn't panic. She had to find a way out. 

She groped her way towards the door. Her hand brushed against the rough wooden wall. She couldn't remember how many doors were in the house. This one must be it. She pushed against the door, but it wouldn't budge. She tried to open it again, but it was jammed. 

Helen took a step back and listened. She thought she heard a faint creaking sound. She couldn't tell where it was coming from. She took a deep breath and called out, "Is someone there?" 

There was no reply. She called out again, her voice louder this time. Still no answer. She took a deep breath and started to feel around the walls for any cracks or openings. She couldn't find anything. 

She was starting to feel afraid. She had to stay calm. She remembered something her father had told her long ago.

text:
Two years ago, I graduated from high school. My father, being an engineer, encouraged me to pursue a career in science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM). Initially, I was unsure as I had a passion for literature and the arts. However, following his advice, I decided to enroll in a engineering degree program. 

At first, the transition from humanities to STEM was challenging. I struggled to understand complex mathematical equations and lab reports. My grades were not impressive and I found myself constantly comparing myself to my peers who seemed to grasp the concepts effortlessly. I felt a deep sense of discouragement and was on the verge of quitting the course. 

However, I refused to give up. I realized that success in STEM is not about possessing a natural ability, but about perseverance, hard work, and determination. I began to study regularly, attended additional tutorials, and asked questions in class to clarify doubts. 

Gradually, things started to improve. I started to understand the concepts better and my grades improved significantly.

story: Helen turned on her flashlight. Nothing happened. The
text:
Helen turned on her flashlight. Nothing happened. The power was out again. She sighed and wished she had a candle. The dark room looked different in the dark. Shadows danced on the walls. A strange noise came from the corner. It sounded like a cat but it was too big. 

Helen took a deep breath. She had to find a match or a lighter. She felt along the wall until her hand touched the box of matches. She struck one and lit it. The flame was small but it was enough to light the room. 

The noise came again. It was a loud banging. Helen's heart raced. She looked around but couldn't see anything. The noise came from upstairs. She wanted to call for help but her phone was dead. She picked up a wooden chair and went upstairs. 

The banging came again. It was coming from the attic door. Helen took a deep breath and pushed it open. A bat flew towards her. She screamed and swung the chair at it. It missed but she heard a growl. 

A big black dog jumped down from the attic. It barked and bared its teeth. Helen backed away.

She had taken French classes in school, but she knew that living in France would provide her with a more immersive learning experience. 

When she first arrived in Paris, Amy was both excited and anxious. The city was larger and more bustling than she had imagined. She felt a little lost in the crowds, but she refused to let her fear hold her back. Amy spent her days exploring the city, taking French classes, and practicing speaking with locals. 

At first, she found it difficult to keep up with the fast-paced conversations. But bit by bit, she started to understand more and more. Amy also discovered that speaking French was not as intimidating as she had thought. With practice, her confidence grew, and she found herself feeling more at home in Paris. 

One of the things Amy enjoyed most about her new life was trying new foods.

label: B1
story:
1 Flappy Bird 
Be careful what you wish for, especially
text:
1 Flappy Bird 
Be careful what you wish for, especially when it comes to popular mobile games. The addictive title Flappy Bird, developed by Vietnamese game creator Dong Nguyen, was once all the rage. Released in 2013, it was a simple tap-to-fly game with a challenging mechanic. Players guided the bird, named after its awkward movements, through pipes, trying to get through each level without touching them. 

The game's simplicity was both its charm and its pitfall. Despite being free to download, Flappy Bird generated significant revenue through in-app ads. However, its addictive nature drew criticism from parents, education institutions, and mental health professionals, who worried about the negative impacts of the game's high level of difficulty and frustration. 

Nguyen, responding to public pressure, removed the game from app stores in early 2014. While it returned briefly before disappearing forever, its moment in the spotlight was over. The brief phenomenon of Flappy Bird serves as a cautionary tale about the power of gaming and the importance of self-control.

text:
Nowadays all the information we could ever need is just a click away. The internet has revolutionized the way we learn new things, communicate with others, and even conduct business. It's a vast, limitless sea of knowledge at our fingertips, but how do we navigate it effectively and efficiently? 

One strategy is to utilize search engines wisely. When formulating a search query, try to use specific and accurate keywords to narrow down the results. For instance, instead of using a general search term like "history," try something more focused like "ancient Egyptian history" or "the industrial revolution." Moreover, using quotation marks to search for exact phrases can yield more precise results. 

Another strategy is to use specialized websites and databases for more detailed and reliable information. Libraries, academic institutions, and professional organizations often have extensive collections of research materials and databases that are accessible to the public. Additionally, citing reputable sources is paramount to ensure the credibility and accuracy of the information gathered.

story: Memorial Day is a United States holiday to remember
text:
Memorial Day is a United States holiday to remember and honor those who have served in the country's military forces. It is observed on the last Monday of May each year. This day is a time for Americans to gather together and pay tribute to their loved ones who have made the ultimate sacrifice while protecting the freedoms and values of our great nation. 

Memorial Day was first observed in the late 1860s, soon after the end of the Civil War. The holiday was initially called Decoration Day because the graves of the fallen soldiers were decorated with flowers and flags. It was later changed to Memorial Day in 1967, and it became a federal holiday in 1971. 

Traditionally, Memorial Day weekend starts the summer season, and many people take advantage of the long weekend to travel, attend parties, and go camping. However, it's essential to remember that the true meaning of this day goes beyond having a nice weekend. It's a time to reflect on the sacrifices that our military personnel and their families have made for our country.

The game's graphics were intentionally low-tech, with a 2D pixel art style that harkened back to the early days of video games.

One book I'd recommend is "Tigers: A Photographic Journey through the World of Tigers" by Steve Winter. This book is filled with stunning photographs of tigers in their natural habitat, along with informative text that discusses the biology, behavior, and conservation of these magnificent creatures. 

Another book that's worth checking out is "The Tiger: A True Story of Vengeance and Survival" by John Vaillant. This is a non-fiction book that tells the true story of a man named Yuri Trush and his quest to protect tigers from poachers in Russia. The book offers a unique insight into the world of tigers and the challenges they face in the modern world. 

Lastly, if you're looking for a children's book about tigers, I'd suggest "The Tiger Who Came to Tea" by Judith Kerr.
