-LRB- CNN -RRB- Craigslist reports about 80 million active monthly users worldwide, making it one of the most widely-used websites for online classified ads. Founded in 2000 by Craig Newmark, the platform was initially designed as an email list for friends to share local happenings and jobs in New York City. However, it quickly expanded and transformed into a global marketplace, providing a wide range of categories for buyers and sellers. 

The website's success can be attributed to its simplicity and ease of use. Users can either search or post ads in various categories like jobs, housing, community, and services. Moreover, Craigslist's local focus allows users to connect with their local communities and buy or sell goods and services within their area. 

One of the most unique features of Craigslist is its absence of a sophisticated interface or marketing strategies. Instead, it maintains a minimalistic design with no graphics or pop-up advertising, focusing more on textual content. While it may not have the visual appeal of other online marketplaces, Craigslist is known for its efficiency in connecting buyers and sellers and the reliability of its listings.

text:
New messages
10 Sep, 00:04 – Israa Al Ahmadi
Hi everyone! I'd be happy to help answer any French language questions you might have. I'm originally from Yemen but have been living in France for the past five years. While improving my French, I faced many challenges and learned some great tips. Let's discuss those together! What difficulties have you come across in your French studies? 

10 Sep, 01:07 – Mariella Rodriguez
Hi Israa,
Nice to meet you! One thing I've been struggling with is the verb conjugation, particularly tenses. I often find myself confused between "je vais" (I go) and "aller" (to go) in the present tense. Could you explain the differences and give some examples? 

10 Sep, 01:12 – Israa Al Ahmadi
Hi Mariella,
Absolutely! "Je vais" is actually a contraction of "Je suis en train de" followed by an infinitive verb (in this case, "aller"). So "Je vais au magasin" would translate to "I am going to the store" in English. On the other hand, "aller" is just the infinitive form of the verb "aller" which means "to go."

label: A1
story: If we look around us at the things we have purchased
text:
If we look around us at the things we have purchased in a grocery store, we can see many different items. There are fruits like apples, bananas, and oranges. There are vegetables such as carrots, broccoli, and tomatoes. There are packaged foods like bread, pasta, and cereal. We also find beverages like juice, milk, and water. 

Fruits and vegetables are important part of a healthy diet. They provide us with essential vitamins and minerals. Apples are sweet and crunchy, perfect for a quick snack. Bananas are great for breakfast with some peanut butter or honey. Oranges are tasty and juicy. Carrots are good for making healthy salads or soups. Broccoli is rich in fiber and vitamin C. Tomatoes are delicious in sandwiches or in salads. 

Packaged foods like bread, pasta, and cereal are convenient options for busy people on the go. Bread is versatile, it can be used to make sandwiches or toast. Pasta is a great base for a variety of meals. Cereal can be eaten for breakfast with milk or yogurt. 

Beverages like juice, milk, and water keep us hydrated.

label: B2
story: Tempier’s condemnation is only one of the approximately
text:
Tempier’s condemnation is only one of the approximately 200 condemnations issued by the Catholic Church between the 13th and 15th centuries against various philosophers and theologians, who were seen as threats to orthodox theology. One of the most prominent among them was the French philosopher and theologian William of Ockham (1288 - 1347), a nominalist, whose ideas were perceived as heretical by the Church. 

Ockham's nominalist philosophy, which holds that universal concepts only exist in the mind and not in reality, was seen as a threat to the Church's teaching on the existence of real, objective properties. In particular, Ockham's doctrine of the "vacuous universals" posited that there are no general terms that refer to anything in reality outside of our thoughts. This idea was perceived as undermining the Church's doctrine of transubstantiation, which holds that during the Eucharist, the bread and wine become the real body and blood of Christ. 

The condemnation of Ockham and his followers was not only issued by the Church but also by secular authorities.

label: C1
story: When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama
text:
When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama 's handling of Super Storm Sandy, it raises eyebrows among the Republican Party. The storm, a massive and devastating weather event, hit the northeastern coast of the United States in October 2012, leaving thousands of people homeless and causing billions of dollars in damage. 

In the aftermath of the storm, Christie, the Republican Governor of New Jersey, received widespread praise for his leadership and his cooperation with the Obama administration. He publicly thanked Obama for his quick response and for providing much-needed assistance to New Jersey. 

However, this display of bipartisanship was a surprise to many in the Republican Party, as Christie is a prominent member and was expected to be a strong critic of the Democratic President. Some saw this as an attempt by Christie to boost his popularity among independent voters, while others accused him of politically motivated actions. 

Regardless of the motivations behind Christie's actions, the storm response served as a reminder that in times of crisis, political affiliations often take a back seat to the needs of the community.

text:
C'mon, guess what?
I don't know, chicken butt?
Stop joking around and let me give you an update on the latest political developments in Europe. 

The European Union has been embroiled in a heated debate over the proposed trade agreement with the United States. The deal, known as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership or TTIP, has been the subject of intense scrutiny from various civil society organizations and politicians. 

The primary concern is that the agreement would weaken EU regulations on food safety, environmental protection, and labor standards, in order to facilitate greater trade between Europe and the US. The fear is that American corporations would be able to challenge EU regulations in special arbitration courts, which would have the power to override national laws. 

The German government has taken a strong stance against TTIP, with Chancellor Merkel expressing her concerns over the implications for German sovereignty and EU regulations. However, the French government, under newly elected President Macron, has expressed a more positive outlook on the deal.

label: A2
story: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under
text:
Many of the major supermarket chains have come under criticism for their business practices. Some people argue that these companies are too large and have too much power in the food industry. They may buy up farmers and suppliers, leaving small businesses with no choice but to sell to them or go out of business. This can lead to higher prices for consumers and a lack of competition. 

Furthermore, some supermarkets have been accused of treating their staff poorly. They may not pay a living wage or offer good working conditions. This can make it difficult for employees to support themselves and their families. 

Another issue is food waste. Supermarkets often sell their produce at a discounted price before it goes bad, which can lead to a surplus of food that is not sold and ends up being thrown away. This is a waste of resources and contributes to greenhouse gas emissions. 

There are steps that can be taken to address these issues. One solution is to support local businesses and farmers instead of relying on major supermarket chains.

story: Do you like cars? Are you friendly and do you like
text:
Do you like cars? Are you friendly and do you like meeting new people? If so, then why not combine your interests by joining a car club? Car clubs offer a welcoming environment where enthusiasts can share their passion for automobiles while building friendships and learning new things. 

Being part of a car club can be a fun and rewarding experience. You'll have the opportunity to attend events, go on road trips, and even learn some mechanical skills from other members. Plus, you'll be surrounded by like-minded people who are always eager to discuss the latest car news and trends. 

One of the best things about being in a car club is the sense of community. Members often help each other out with repairs, offer advice, and provide support during events. Plus, there's a certain level of camaraderie that comes from sharing a common hobby. 

Another great benefit of joining a car club is the opportunity to expand your horizons. You'll be exposed to different makes and models of cars that you might not otherwise encounter.

story:
To:
James Forrester
Date:
6 November
Subject:
Possible
text:
To:
James Forrester
Date:
6 November
Subject:
Possible Solutions for the Current Water Scarcity Crisis in Our City

Dear James,

I hope this email finds you well. I was deeply disturbed by the recent news regarding the worsening water scarcity crisis in our city, which is affecting not only our daily lives but also the environment. In light of this pressing issue, I have gathered some insights from reputable sources that may potentially contribute to alleviating the problem. 

First and foremost, we should focus on rainwater harvesting as a feasible and cost-effective solution. This can be achieved through the installation of rainwater harvesting systems in individual households and public buildings. Rainwater harvesting not only reduces the demand for municipal water but also ensures a constant water supply during droughts. Additionally, the use of greywater from sinks, baths, and showers can also be employed to water gardens, flush toilets, and clean floors, thereby reducing the pressure on the water supply.

label: B2
story: Helen was outside watering her lawn like she does every
text:
Helen was outside watering her lawn like she does every evening after work. The sun was slowly setting, casting long shadows over the garden. She could hear the distant sound of children playing in the park and the gentle chirping of birds in the trees. It was a peaceful scene that she always looked forward to after a long day. 

As she moved from one patch of grass to another, Helen couldn't help but notice the small patch of weeds that had grown in between the blades of grass. Sighing, she reached down to pluck them out one by one. As she worked, she began to ponder over her day. 

Her boss had given her an important project to work on, which she had been putting off for a few days. She knew she should have started on it earlier, but she had been overwhelmed with other tasks. Now, she felt the pressure mounting and didn't know where to begin. 

Suddenly, she heard the sound of a garden hose turning on. Looking up, she saw her neighbor, Tom, coming out of his house with a hose in hand. "Evening, Helen," he greeted her with a friendly smile.

story: A 4-year-old Ohio girl who vanished more than three
text:
A 4-year-old Ohio girl who vanished more than three weeks ago was found safe and sound in a shocking turn of events. The little girl, named Madalyn, was discovered in a wooded area near her home. Her family is overjoyed after a long period of uncertainty and fear. 

"We cannot believe it. We've been praying for this moment," Madalyn's grandmother said with tears in her eyes. "We are so grateful for the community's help and support during this difficult time." 

Authorities stated that Madalyn's safe return is a testament to the effectiveness of their extensive search efforts and community involvement. However, the investigation is still ongoing, and police are urging the public to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activities in their neighborhoods. 

"We are still gathering evidence to determine how Madalyn went missing and how she ended up where she was found," a police spokesperson said. "We want to thank everyone who helped in any way during this search." 

Madalyn will undergo medical checks to ensure her wellbeing before being reunited with her family.

label: B1
story: The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a
text:
The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a report that China may be planning to send a massive military convoy, possibly involving hundreds of vessels, to the Taiwan Strait. Spokesperson Jen Psaki urged Beijing to avoid taking any steps that could raise tensions in the strategically crucial waterway. 

The Taiwan Strait separates Taiwan, a self-governing democracy, from China, which claims the island as part of its territory. The strait is one of the world's busiest waterways, with shipping traffic worth hundreds of billions of dollars passing through it annually. 

Psaki told reporters during her daily briefing that the US has a vital interest in maintaining peace and stability in the region. "We call on China to cease its military, diplomatic, and economic pressure against Taiwan," she added. 

The report of the Chinese military convoy, first published by Taiwan's Central News Agency, came amid heightened tension between Beijing and Washington over Taiwan. China has long claimed the self-governing island as part of its territory and opposes any external involvement in its affairs.

label: B2
story: Texas Gov. Rick Perry's decision to send up to 1,000
text:
Texas Gov. Rick Perry's decision to send up to 1,000 National Guard troops to the southern border has been met with controversy and debate. On one hand, Perry argues that the deployment is necessary to help secure the border and deter illegal immigration. On the other hand, critics argue that the move is politically motivated and a waste of taxpayer resources. 

Perry, who is seeking the Republican nomination for president, has been a vocal critic of the federal government's handling of border security. He claims that the Obama administration has failed to secure the border and has put American communities at risk. In a statement, Perry said, "As long as the federal government continues to fail in its duty to secure our southern border, I will not stand idly by and watch the citizens of Texas and our nation be put at risk." 

Critics, however, argue that the deployment is a political stunt intended to boost Perry's profile as a tough-on-immigration candidate. They point out that illegal border crossings have been declining in recent years and that the troops will not be authorized to make arrests or engage in law enforcement activities.

label: C1
story: Protesters in a Turkish border town hit by a twin car-bombing
text:
Protesters in a Turkish border town hit by a twin car-bombing that left over 30 people dead and hundreds more injured took to the streets once again, demanding justice and expressing their anger towards the government's perceived inaction. The explosions, claimed by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), marked a significant escalation in violence in the restive region despite ongoing peace talks between the rebels and Ankara. 

Amidst a heavy police presence, demonstrators chanted anti-government slogans, waved Kurdish flags and carried signs denouncing the ongoing conflict. Many voiced their frustrations over the lack of progress in the peace negotiations, as well as the government's failure to provide adequate security in the affected areas. 

In response, the authorities declared a curfew in several districts of the province and cut off internet access, citing "security concerns." The move was widely criticized by civil society organizations and human rights groups as a violation of freedom of expression. 

The situation in the region has been a source of tension for decades, with both sides accusing each other of human rights abuses and violence.

label: A2
story: A 4-year-old Ohio girl who vanished more than three
text:
A 4-year-old Ohio girl who vanished more than three years ago was found alive and well in Missouri on Sunday. The girl, named Amanda Berry, managed to escape from the home where she was being held captive along with six-year-old Gina DeJesus and 14-year-old Michelle Knight in Cleveland. They were all abducted by the same man, Ariel Castro. 

Amanda, who was just nine when she disappeared in 2003, managed to break free from her captor while he was outside of the house. She then ran to a neighbor's house to call the police. Both Amanda and Gina, who were reported missing at the same time, have been reunited with their families and are in a good condition. Michelle Knight, who was taken in 2002, was also found in the same house and was freed. 

The three women were held in the basement of Castro's house, which is located on Seymour Avenue, in the city's gritty Tremont neighborhood. The girls went missing just blocks away from their homes. Castro, who is a registered sex offender, lured them into his home using false pretenses.

text:
-LRB- CNN -RRB- Craigslist reports about 80 million active users per month, making it one of the largest online platforms for buying and selling goods and services. The website has become so popular that it's available in over 700 cities around the world. It was founded in 1995 by Craig Newmark as an email list for friends in New York City to exchange information. Nowadays, Craigslist offers various categories, including housing, jobs, services, for sale, community, and resale. 

One of its most notable features is its simplicity. Users can easily create a free account and post ads, communicate with others through email, and browse listings in their area. Unlike other marketplaces, Craigslist doesn't charge buyers or sellers any fees. However, this lack of oversight can also lead to scams or safety concerns. Therefore, it's essential to exercise caution when using the site and follow certain precautions, such as meeting in public places when buying or selling items, not sharing personal information, and avoiding cash transactions.

And let me tell you, trying to order food in a restaurant without knowing the local words for "please," "thank you," or "cheese" can be quite a challenge. 
That being said, learning a new language can be daunting, especially when you're not sure where to start. But fear not, my dear language learner, for I've got some tips up my sleeve to help you get started. 
First and foremost, set realistic goals for yourself. Learning a new language takes time and dedication, so don't overwhelm yourself by trying to master it all at once. Instead, focus on the basics: greetings, numbers, and common expressions. 
Next, immerse yourself in the language as much as possible. Watch TV shows, listen to music, or read books in the target language.

label: C1
story: There may be no greater entertainer in the history
text:
There may be no greater entertainer in the history of music than the inimitable Michael Jackson. Known as the "King of Pop," Jackson's innovative style and electrifying performances continue to captivate fans around the world. Born on August 29, 1958, in Gary, Indiana, Jackson's musical journey began at a young age. 

As the lead singer of the Jackson 5, a family band that rose to fame in the late 1960s, Jackson showed an early aptitude for performing and songwriting. However, it was his solo career that would truly solidify his place in music history. With iconic singles such as "Billie Jean," "Thriller," and "Beat It," Jackson pushed the boundaries of popular music, blending elements of R&B, pop, and dance into a unique and captivating sound. 

But Jackson was not just a talented musician; he was also a groundbreaking artist and cultural icon. His music videos, which were often innovative and visually stunning, helped to popularize the medium and set new standards for visual storytelling in music. "Thriller," which was released in 1982, is arguably the most successful music video of all time, earning a record-breaking 14 MTV Awards and cementing Jackson's status as a trailblazer in the music industry.

label: C2
story: The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a
text:
The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a French court's decision to seize assets of an American oil company in the Caribbean, warning it could have serious consequences on US-French relations. The French court's ruling, which came in response to a longstanding dispute between Paris and the energy firm, Total, over drilling licenses in the Guyana marine territory, is perceived as a direct challenge to American economic interests. 

The White House spokesperson, in a statement, expressed deep concern over the "unilateral actions taken by the French government" and urged Paris to reconsider the decision, which, in the words of the administration, "undermines confidence in the rule of law and the predictability of the international business environment." The statement further added that the move could potentially harm the already strained bilateral ties between the two nations. 

The French court's order to freeze Total's assets, including six ships, came in response to a complaint filed by a consortium of French fishing firms, arguing that Total's drilling could harm their livelihoods.

label: A1
story: It's not going to be Batman versus Superman versus
text:
It's not going to be Batman versus Superman versus Spiderman today. It's only Batman and Robin, working together to save the city from Joker's latest evil plan. 

Batman sat in the Batcave, analyzing the situation. "Robin, we have a problem. Joker has taken hostages at the Gotham Museum." 

Robin's voice came through the communicator. "Understood, Batman. I'll meet you there right away." 

Batman drove the Batmobile through the streets of Gotham, sirens blaring. He arrived at the museum and saw Joker, wearing his signature purple suit and green hair, standing on a balcony, laughing maniacally. 

"Batman! You're too late!" Joker called down to him. "I have the hostages and I won't let them go until you give in to my demands!" 

Batman climbed up to the balcony using a grappling hook. "What do you want, Joker?" he asked, trying to keep his voice calm. 

Joker laughed. "Why, world domination of course! And you'll help me get it!" 

Batman shook his head. "Never. I'll stop you, no matter what." 

Joker grinned. "Let's see if you're really as brave as you think you are, Batman."

label: B1
story: When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama
text:
When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama for his leadership during natural disasters, it might come as a surprise to some. The two men, who come from different political parties, have had their fair share of disagreements and public disputes. However, when Hurricane Sandy hit the eastern seaboard of the United States in 2012, Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, sought help from the Democratic president, who quickly responded with federal aid. 

After the storm had passed, Christie thanked Obama for his swift action. He praised the president's quick response and the resources the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provided to help in the relief effort. "When the president came to New Jersey, I think he did an excellent job in terms of being present, being compassionate, being hands-on, and understanding the plight of people in New Jersey that are suffering," Christie said in an interview. 

Although their political differences remained, the moment of crisis brought the two men together.

label: C1
story: Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans
text:
Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans who have left an indelible mark on the history of civil rights in the United States. Born on January 15, 1929, in Atlanta, Georgia, King became a leading voice in the fight for racial equality through nonviolent means. 

King's activism began in earnest in the 1950s, when he led the Montgomery Bus Boycott in response to the arrest of Rosa Parks, a black woman who refused to give up her seat on a bus to a white passenger. The boycott lasted for over a year and ultimately led to the desegregation of Montgomery's public bus system. 

King's leadership and eloquence were instrumental in advancing the civil rights movement. He gave numerous speeches, the most famous of which is arguably his "I Have a Dream" speech, delivered during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom in 1963. In this speech, King called for an end to racism and urged unity and equality among all Americans. 

Despite facing immense opposition, King remained committed to nonviolent protest and civil disobedience.

story: It's not going to be Batman versus Superman versus
text:
It's not going to be Batman versus Superman versus Spider-Man today, it's just me and you. I want to share with you some interesting facts about comic books and their superheroes. I'll keep it simple, so we can all understand. 

First, did you know that comic books have a long history? The first American superhero comic book appeared in 1933! It was called "Funnies on Parade" and featured a superhero named Funnyman. But the most well-known superheroes, like Superman and Batman, didn't come along until the late 1930s. 

Superman, also known as "The Man of Steel," is from the planet Krypton. He came to Earth as a baby when his home planet was destroyed. Superman has incredible powers like super strength, x-ray vision, super speed, and more. He uses these powers to protect the people of Metropolis and keep them safe. 

Batman, also known as the "Dark Knight," doesn't have any superpowers. But he is incredibly smart and wealthy, which helps him fight crime in Gotham City. He wears a cool costume and uses gadgets to help him out in his battles against crime.

label: C1
story: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions.
text:
The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions. Its exceptional landscape, characterized by its red clay and ancient kasbahs, has been the set of numerous movies and series, some of which are internationally renowned. 

Among these productions, the fortified city of Aït Benhaddou, situated at a mere 35 kilometers away from Ouarzazate, has been the backdrop for films such as Gladiator, Lawrence of Arabia, and most recently, the Game of Thron es series, where it served as a location for the fictional city of Yunkai. The site, with its beautiful and intricate architecture, offers a breathtaking view of the Atlas Mountains and a glimpse into Morocco's rich history. 

Moreover, the Atlas Film Studios, located in close proximity to Ouarzazate, hosts major international film productions. Some of the most notable movies shot on its grounds are The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor, The Gladiator, and Alexander. This studio is not merely a tourist attraction, but an essential hub for movie production in Morocco.

text:

I'm thinking about "The Little Mermaid." Have you seen it before? 
Not yet, but I've heard it's a classic. We can rent some popcorn and enjoy the show together.

Okay, I'll meet you there around seven. See you soon! 
Looking forward to it! 
Bye for now. Goodbye. 

After the movie, we chatted about our opinions. Anthony thought the music was beautiful, while Emily enjoyed the underwater scenes. They agreed to go to the ice cream shop for dessert. They laughed and talked about their favorite parts of the film during the drive home. It was a fun evening. 

Anthony and Emily decided to have more movie nights together. They watched comedies, action films, and dramas. They shared their opinions, snacks, and laughter throughout each movie experience. It helped them bond and create cherished memories. The end. 

I hope you enjoyed this little story!

label: B2
story: The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a
text:
The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a recent report that the Russian military had built new underground facilities in Crimea, which was annexed by Moscow in 2014. The structures, revealed in satellite images, were said to be large enough to house ballistic missiles. The findings came from the Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) group, Bellingcat, which has previously published detailed reports on Russia's activities in Ukraine and Syria. 

The Kremlin, however, dismissed the report as false. Spokesperson Dmitry Peskov told state news agency TASS that Russia had no plans to deploy any new military hardware in Crimea and that the satellite images showed nothing more than "natural geological formations." 

The White House, in a statement, said it was closely monitoring the situation in the region and that any "potential provocative actions" could have serious consequences. The Ukrainian government, which continues to claim sovereignty over Crimea, expressed concern over the report and urged the international community to take note of Russia's actions.

label: C2
story: When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama
text:
When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama 's handling of Hurricane Sandy, it may come as a surprise to some. The Republican governor of New Jersey, known for his sharp criticisms of the Democratic president, went on national television just days after the devastating storm struck in 2012 to express his gratitude for Obama's swift response. 

Christie had no qualms about publicly acknowledging his appreciation for the federal aid that poured in to help rebuild the areas most affected by the storm surge. He even went as far as to say that the disaster response was a "bright spot in a dark time," and that the president "did what he needed to do, and did it very well." 

This unexpected display of bipartisanship did not go unnoticed. It was a powerful reminder of the importance of effective leadership during times of crisis, and how politics can take a back seat to the needs of the people. 

But it was not just Obama's quick action that impressed Chris Christie. He also praised the president's empathy and emotional intelligence.

This business model has allowed Craigslist to cater to a wider audience, especially those who cannot afford high transaction fees.

The government has long accused the PKK of being a terrorist organization and has launched multiple military offensives against the group over the years. 

Meanwhile, the international community, including the European Union, has called for an end to violence and urged both sides to engage in a peaceful dialogue.

label: A2
story: Buber’s best-known work is the short philosophical
text:
Buber’s best-known work is the short philosophical text "I and Thou" (1923). In this work, Buber explores the fundamental nature of human relationships. He distinguishes between two types of relationships: I-Thou and I-It. 

In an I-Thou relationship, the Other is seen as a unique and independent being. This relationship is characterized by dialogue, respect, and mutual understanding. For Buber, God is the ultimate I-Thou: we relate to God as a separate, personal being, rather than as an object or concept. 

On the other hand, in an I-It relationship, the Other is seen as an object or thing. This relationship is characterized by manipulation, control, and domination. Buber argues that we can only lead a fulfilled and authentic life if we engage in I-Thou relationships with other people and with the natural world. 

Buber also believed in the importance of living in the present moment. He believed that we should not focus too much on the past or the future, as this can prevent us from truly experiencing the richness of the present.

Local leaders have criticized the government's response to the attacks, saying that it has not done enough to address the root causes of the conflict and prevent further bloodshed.

story: There may be no greater entertainer in the history
text:
There may be no greater entertainer in the history of music than Elvis Presley. The charismatic American singer, actor, and musician, often referred to as the "King of Rock and Roll," captivated audiences with his distinctive voice, dynamic performances, and irresistible stage presence. Born on January 8, 1935, in Tupelo, Mississippi, Elvis's unique combination of blues, country, and gospel influences shaped him into a musical icon. 

Growing up during the Great Depression, Elvis's family was not wealthy. Nevertheless, his mother, Gladys, instilled in him a deep love for music. Elvis received his first guitar, a Christmas present, when he was only 11 years old. The young boy honed his guitar skills, and soon he was performing local gigs and singing on street corners. After high school, he moved to Memphis, Tennessee, with dreams of a career in music. 

The turning point in Elvis's career came on August 10, 1954, when he recorded "That's All Right," a song by bluesman Arthur Crudup. The single, released by Sun Records, became a regional hit and brought him to the attention of major record labels.

label: A1
story: Buber’s best-known work is the short philosophical
text:
Buber’s best-known work is the short philosophical novel "I and Thou." In this book, he distinguishes between the way we relate to objects and the way we relate to other people. When we relate to objects, such as a table or a tree, Buber calls it an "I-it" relationship. We use them, shape them, or manipulate them to fit our needs. On the other hand, when we relate to people, Buber refers to it as an "I-thou" relationship. Here, we encounter the other person as a unique and independent being, who exists beyond ourselves, and we engage with them in a dialogue. 

This "I-thou" relationship is characterized by respect, openness, and authenticity. Buber believes that it is essential to cultivate this kind of relationship not only with other people but also with the natural world. He sees this as a way to live a more meaningful and authentic life. 

Buber was a German-Jewish philosopher and sociologist. He was born in Austria in 1878 and died in Israel in 1965. He wrote many other works on philosophy, education, and religion.

Intricately crafted plots, richly drawn characters, and a profound understanding of the human condition are the hallmarks of his literary legacy. 

Born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England, in 1564, Shakespeare received a modest education in grammar school, which provided him with the foundation to develop his exceptional writing skills. label: B1
story: Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans
text:
Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans in history. He was born on January 15, 1929, in Atlanta, Georgia. King grew up in a loving and religious family. As a young man, he attended Crozer Theological Seminary in Pennsylvania and later received a doctorate in systematic theology from Boston University. 

King became a pastor in Alabama, where he led the Montgomery Bus Boycott in 1955. The boycott was started after Rosa Parks, a black woman, was arrested for refusing to give up her seat on a bus to a white person. The boycott lasted for over a year and eventually led to the desegregation of Montgomery's buses. 

King's activism for civil rights continued throughout the 1950s and 1960s. He gave many powerful speeches, including his famous "I Have a Dream" speech, delivered during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom in 1963. This speech helped to rally support for civil rights legislation and brought international attention to the cause. 

King was also a leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC).

story:

text:
Hello, Mr. Smith. It's nice to finally meet you.
Likewise, Mrs. Johnson. I've heard a lot about you from my colleagues. 

Let's move on to the topic of today's lesson: verbs, specifically irregular verbs. I know some of you might be thinking, "Oh no, not verbs again!" But don't worry, it won't be as complicated as it seems. 

Irregular verbs, unlike regular verbs, don't follow the usual pattern for forming their past tense and past participle. For example, the verb "go" changes to "went" in the past and "gone" in the past participle. Another example is the verb "eat," which becomes "ate" in the past and "eaten" in the past participle. 

Now, let's try a little exercise to test your knowledge of irregular verbs. Fill in the blank with the correct form of the verb in parentheses. 

1. Yesterday, I \_\_\_\_\_ (be) at the gym. 
2. After eating the sandwich, he \_\_\_\_\_ (feel) very full. 
3. We \_\_\_\_\_ (have) this discussion many times before. 
4. He \_\_\_\_\_ (meet) his new neighbor last week. 
5. She \_\_\_\_\_ (take) a long nap and missed the appointment.

story: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions.
text:
The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions. It's no stranger to the international film industry, as its unique landscapes have been the backdrop for numerous movies and television shows. From "Gladiator" and "Lawrence of Arabia" to "Game of Thrones" and "Jesus of Nazareth," Ouarzazate's rugged beauty has captured the imagination of audiences worldwide. 

The sun-scorched earth seems almost alive in its harsh splendor, the red, orange, and yellow hues painting a picture of desolation and grandeur. The city's fortresses and kasbahs, some still inhabited, stand tall in the midst of this seemingly inhospitable terrain. 

The most famous of these is the Aït Benhaddou kasbah, a UNESCO World Heritage site. This ancient citadel, made of clay, has been standing strong for centuries, its architecture a testament to the Berber civilization. The kasbah's intricate designs and towering structures are a photographer's dream. 

But Ouarzazate is not just a place for filmmakers and tourists. It's a place of culture and tradition, where the Berber people maintain their age-old customs and ways of life.

Moreover, Ouarzazate is home to several film studios, including Atlas Film Studios and Cinecittà, which have hosted various well-known productions such as "Game of Thrones," "Lawrence of Arabia," "The Mummy," and "The Gl adiator," to name a few. story: Veterans Day is an official United States holiday observed
text:
Veterans Day is an official United States holiday observed annually on November 11 to honor and thank all who have served in the armed forces. It is also known as Armistice Day, which commemorates the end of World War I. On this day, various towns and cities across the country hold parades, ceremonies, and events to honor those who served their country. 

Many people wear red poppies as a symbol of respect and remembrance. The tradition of wearing poppies on Veterans Day comes from the poem "In Flanders Fields," by John McCrae, a Canadian military doctor. In the poem, McCrae describes the landscape of the battlefield covered in red poppies, which bloomed amidst the destruction of war. 

Veterans Day is a time to express our gratitude to all the brave men and women who have served in the military. It's an opportunity to show our appreciation for their sacrifices, dedication, and bravery. We can honor veterans by offering them a simple "thank you" or by volunteering our time to help support organizations that assist veterans and their families.

story: Tempier’s condemnation is only one of the approximately
text:
Tempier’s condemnation is only one of the approximately 200 condemnations that the Catholic Church issued during the Middle Ages. These condemnations were used to maintain orthodoxy and discipline within the Church. The most famous one is the Condemnation of 1210, which targeted Aristotle and the philosophers. Let's discuss some other notable condemnations. 

The Condemnation of 1225 targeted Peter Abelard, a famous theologian who was known for his rationalist approach to theology. The condemnation focused on his views of the Trinity and the role of faith versus reason. Abelard was not present when the condemnation was issued, as he was in exile in England at the time. However, many of his works were burned. 

The Condemnation of 1231 was issued by Robert the Quarrelsome, the Bishop of Paris. He targeted the works of William of Saint-Thomas, also known as William of Moerbeke, who translated many Aristotelian texts into Latin. The condemnation targeted 219 errors found in these texts and led to a renewed interest in Aristotelian philosophy within the academic community.

Veterans Day is an important day to remember and honor those who have served in the military.

story: Helen was outside watering her lawn like she does every
text:
Helen was outside watering her lawn like she does every morning. It was a beautiful sunny day, and the birds were singing in the trees. She loved this quiet time of the day. Her neighbor, Tom, who lived next door, came out of his house with his dog, Max. Max was a big, fluffy golden retriever. 

"Good morning, Tom!" Helen greeted him cheerfully. 

"Morning, Helen. How's your day going?" Tom asked as he scooped up Max's poop with a plastic bag. 

"It's only just started, but it's off to a good begin. How about yours?" Helen replied, smiling. 

"Pretty good, actually. I have a meeting with my boss later, but I think it's going to be a positive one," Tom responded. 

Helen and Tom chatted for a few minutes about their gardens and their pets. Max barked happily, wagging his tail between them. The sun was warming Helen's back as she watered her plants. She felt grateful for this peaceful moment in the morning. 

"Well, I better get back to work, Tom. Have a great day," Helen said, waving goodbye. 

"You too, Helen.

story: Tempier’s condemnation is only one of the approximately
text:
Tempier’s condemnation is only one of the approximately 217 condemnations issued by the Catholic Church against various philosophers and theologians during the 13th and 14th centuries. This period is often referred to as the "Age of Faith and Reason." These condemnations were issued by the Catholic Church's highest judicial body, the papal Inquisition, to protect orthodoxy and suppress heretical ideas. 

Tempier's condemnation is notable for its extensive scope, as it covers a wide range of philosophical and theological questions. Among the condemned propositions, we can find statements about God, the universe, knowledge, freedom, and causality. For example, some propositions questioned God's omniscience or denied the existence of eternal truths. Others challenged Aristotelian physics or suggested that the material world is the primary source of knowledge. 

It is important to note that the condemned propositions do not necessarily reflect the views of the philosophers or theologians themselves. Sometimes, they are the result of misinterpretations or misquotations.

story: Texas Gov. Rick Perry's decision to send up to 1,000
text:
Texas Gov. Rick Perry's decision to send up to 1,000 National Guard troops to the U. S.- Mexico border caused a lot of controversy. Some people believe this move is necessary to keep the border secure and protect American citizens. Others think it's a waste of resources and a political stunt. 

The border between the two countries is a long and porous one, stretching over 1,900 miles. Many believe that the U. S. government should do more to secure it. They argue that illegal immigration is a major problem, and that it brings with it crime, disease, and an economic burden. They also point out that border security is a federal responsibility. 

Opponents of the troop deployment argue that it's a costly, ineffective solution to a complex problem. They point out that the border is a vast area, and that it's impossible to completely secure it. They also argue that National Guard troops are not trained to do border patrol work, and that their presence could even make the situation worse by provoking tensions with Mexico.

story: Texas Gov. Rick Perry's decision to send up to 1,000
text:
Texas Gov. Rick Perry's decision to send up to 1,000 National Guards to the border with Mexico has drawn both support and controversy. Some Americans believe it's necessary to secure the border and protect their community. Others argue it's a waste of resources and creates tension between Texas and Mexico. 

Perry made the announcement on August 6, 2014. He said the troops will provide vehicle and foot patrols, operate surveillance cameras and help process immigration paperwork. The move came after a surge in unaccompanied minors and families from Central America crossed the border in recent months, overwhelming border facilities. 

Supporters of the move say it's a response to the Obama administration's failure to secure the border. They believe the presence of National Guards will deter illegal immigrants from crossing and help prevent crime. 

Critics argue that the troops are not trained border guards and that their deployment is a misuse of resources. They also worry that the troops' presence may lead to misunderstandings or even conflicts with Mexican authorities or civilians.

Do you like cars? Are you friendly and do you like making new friends? If your answers are yes, then I have an interesting topic for you! In this writing, I'd like to talk about how owning a car can help you meet new people and expand your social circle. 

Firstly, imagine sitting in a crowded bus during your daily commute. You can see many people around you, but you might not have the courage to start a conversation. However, when you're driving a car, things can be different. You can wave at the driver next to you or give a friendly honk when they make a mistake. These small gestures can be the start of a conversation that might lead to a new friendship. 

Moreover, when you're stopped at a red light or waiting in a traffic jam, you can strike up a conversation with the person in the car next to you. You can talk about the weather, the traffic or anything that comes to mind. These conversations can lead to interesting exchanges and new connections. 

Additionally, joining a car club is another great way to meet people who share the same passion for cars as you.

story: The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a
text:
The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a report in the Turkish media that U. S. military aircraft targeted a convoy of Syrian government forces near the country's northeastern border with Iraq. 

The report, which appeared in several Turkish newspapers, claimed that two U. S. warplanes attacked Syrian tanks and troops in the area of the town of Qamishli late Tuesday. 

However, the U. S. military's Central Command denied the claims, issuing a statement that read, "We are aware of the reports, but have no information to confirm the details." 

The incident comes as tensions between the Syrian government and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, which are backed by the United States, have risen in recent days following clashes near the border town of Kobani. 

The Syrian army has accused the SDF of attacking Syrian positions and has threatened to retaliate if the Kurdish forces do not withdraw from areas along the border. 

The situation is complicated by the presence of U. S. troops in the region, who are helping to train and advise the SDF in their fight against the Islamic State militant group.

story: When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama
text:
When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama , it may come as a surprise to some. After all, Christie, a Republican governor from New Jersey, has long been known for his harsh criticism of the Democratic president. However, during a speech in New Orleans on February 4, 2015, Christie had nothing but praise for Obama's handling of the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. 

Christie, who was a U. S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey at the time of Katrina, recalled that the president "took control of a very difficult situation and he provided resources and leadership to get things done in New Orleans." He went on to say "the federal government did its job." 

This unexpected statement came after years of criticism from Christie and other Republican leaders towards Obama's response to the 2005 hurricane. The storm, which struck New Orleans and the Gulf Coast region, caused widespread destruction and resulted in over 1,200 deaths. The federal response was initially criticized for its slow and inadequate assistance to the affected areas.

Dear James,

story: The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a
text:
The White House Wednesday said it was puzzled by a recent statement from North Korea threatening a "serious physical response" if the US continues to provoke Pyongyang with joint military exercises with South Korea. 

"We remain committed to the peace and stability of the Korean Peninsula, and to the denuclearization of the peninsula," said a White House spokesperson. "Dialogue and diplomacy remain our preferred way to address these issues." 

The statement came a day after North Korea's state media called the ongoing joint military drills between the US and South Korea a "rehearsal for an invasion." The drills have been an annual event for decades, but North Korea views them as a provocation. 

The US and South Korea have downplayed the significance of the exercises, saying they are defensive in nature and not a threat to North Korea. 

But North Korea is not convinced. "We will be closely watching every move by the enemy," a statement from North Korea's Foreign Ministry said, warning of "serious physical response."

story: Protesters in a Turkish border town hit by a twin car-bombing
text:
Protesters in a Turkish border town hit by a twin car-bombing last week continued their demonstrations for a third day yesterday, demanding answers from their government. The explosions, which occurred on the outskirts of the town, killed eight people and injured many more. 

Local residents, who say they have been living in fear of violence spilling over from neighboring Syria, took to the streets with banners and chanting slogans, expressing their anger and calling for security and protection. 

"Why aren't the authorities doing anything to keep us safe?" asked Fatima, a mother of three who lost her husband in the explosion. "Every day we live in fear of another attack. We need more police and more soldiers here to protect us." 

The Turkish government has condemned the attacks, which they have blamed on the Kurdish militant organization, the PKK. However, some residents say they do not trust the government's explanation and believe that more could have been done to prevent the bombings. 

"The Turkish government always talks about defeating the PKK, but they never do enough to protect the civilians living near the border," said Ali, a shopkeeper who witnessed the explosions.

-LRB- Exercise -RRB- Exercise is important, but it can be hard to find the motivation sometimes. I like to run, because it's free and I can do it anywhere. But, sometimes I skip a day or two, and I feel bad about it. Maybe I should try a gym or join a class?

story: There may be no greater entertainer in the history
text:
There may be no greater entertainer in the history of show business than Charlie Chaplin. Born on April 16, 1889, in London, England, Charlie was an actor, composer, filmmaker, and a brilliant comedian who made people laugh in silent films during the early 20th century. He became famous for his iconic character, the Tramp, who wore a bowler hat, a cane, and a ragged suit. 

Charlie's childhood was not an easy one. He had a difficult relation with his alcoholic father and a step-mother who did not care for him much. He was mostly raised by his maternal half-brother, who ran a music hall. Charlie started performing in various music halls and vaudeville shows when he was only 7 years old. 

In 1913, Charlie moved to the United States and began working for the Keystone Film Company. He made several short films, most of which featured his comedic genius, but it wasn't until 1914 that he created the Tramp character in "Kid Auto Races at Venice." The Tramp became an instant hit, and Charlie became a household name. 

Charlie created a unique style of comedy in silent films that relied more on physical humor and facial expressions than dialogue.

label: A2
story: Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans
text:
Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans in history. He was born on January 15, 1929 in Atlanta, Georgia. King became a civil rights activist who fought for equality and an end to discrimination against African Americans. His most famous speech was the "I Have a Dream" speech, which he delivered on August 28, 1963 in front of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D. C. 

King grew up in a loving and religious family. He attended segregated schools and colleges, which meant that African Americans and whites were separated. This was a common practice during that time. King completed his studies and became a minister, which is a religious leader. 

In 1955, King led a successful boycott of the Montgomery buses in Alabama. This was a protest against the policy of seating African Americans at the back of the bus. The boycott lasted for over a year and ended when the policy was changed. This was an important victory for the civil rights movement. 

King continued to speak out against discrimination and injustice.

label: A1
story: When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama
text:
When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama , it's a big surprise. Chris Christie is a well-known Republican politician from New Jersey, USA. Usually, Republicans don't agree with Democrats like Obama. But in October 2020, Chris Christie spoke about Obama in a positive way. 

At a virtual conference, Christie commended Obama for his leadership during the 2012 Hurricane Sandy. Chris Christie said, "President Obama did a great job for us. He was there for us when we needed him." This is a kind compliment. 

Hurricane Sandy hit the eastern coast of the United States in late 2012. It caused a lot of damage to New Jersey and other states. Chris Christie asked for federal help from Obama. Obama sent help right away. The aid included money, food, and supplies for people who lost their homes. 

Chris Christie thanked Obama for his quick response and the assistance. He showed that even politicians can work together for the good of their constituents, no matter their political differences. This is a valuable lesson for all of us.

story: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions.
text:
The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions. Its unique landscapes have attracted many filmmakers from around the world. Some movies and shows that were filmed there are Gladiator, Lawrence of Arabia, and the famous Game of Thrones series. 

Ouarzazate looks like a moonscape with its vast, desert-like terrain dotted with rugged mountains. The city has two main attractions: the Atlas Film Studios and the Taourirt Kasbah. 

Atlas Film Studios is where you can visit sets from various productions. You can walk through the gates of Westeros and stand where Daenerys Targaryen's armies once marched. The studio also offers tours that take you behind the scenes and explain the filmmaking process. 

Taourirt Kasbah is a traditional Berber fortress that dates back to the 19th century. Its high walls and narrow streets provide a window into the past. A visit to the kasbah is like taking a step back in time, offering a glimpse of what life was like in Morocco before modern times. 

The city of Ouarzazate is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in film and history.

Subject:

Hello James,

I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to you about a possible trip I am planning to London. I have always wanted to visit this beautiful city and see its famous landmarks. 

Firstly, I need to arrange my travel dates. I would like to go there for a week, but I am still deciding on the exact dates. I will let you know as soon as I have made a decision. 

Next, I need to book my flight. I would like to fly from Madrid Barajas International Airport. Do you know if there are cheap flights from this airport to London? Or should I fly from another airport nearby? 

I also need to find a place to stay in London. I would like to stay in a budget hostel or a cheap hotel. Can you recommend any good options for me? I would appreciate it. 

Furthermore, I would like to explore London on a tight budget. Do you have any suggestions for free or cheap activities I can do there? 

I will be grateful for any advice or help you can give me, James.

Yes, I enjoy playing the guitar and taking long walks in the park.

story: Protesters in a Turkish border town hit by a twin car-bombing
text:
Protesters in a Turkish border town hit by a twin car-bombing gathered in the town square, holding candles and chanting for peace. The explosion, which occurred just a few hours ago, left many injured and a number of people dead. Emergency services worked tirelessly to help the victims, transporting the wounded to hospitals in neighboring cities. 

The blast happened near a market, where shoppers were preparing their weekly grocery shopping. Families were out, children playing around, when suddenly the sound of the explosion echoed through the streets. The scene was one of chaos and destruction. Buildings were damaged and debris littered the streets. The town's residents were shocked and saddened by this senseless act of violence. 

The government strongly condemned the attack and assured its citizens that measures would be taken to ensure their safety. The prime minister held an emergency meeting with security officials to discuss the situation. 

The town's people are calling for peace and a return to normalcy.

story: Chemical dispersants keep flowing into the Gulf of
text:
Chemical dispersants keep flowing into the Gulf of Mexico as the oil spill from the ruptured wellhead continues to expand. The disaster began on April 20, 2010, when an explosion on the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig left 11 workers dead and caused a massive oil leak. 

Now, workers are working around the clock to contain the spill and prevent further damage. They use large containers to collect the oil that rises to the surface. However, due to the size and depth of the spill, it's a daunting task. To help break up the oil and make it more manageable, they sprinkle chemical dispersants over the slick. 

The dispersants work by breaking up the oil into smaller droplets which are then carried down into the water and away from the surface. This prevents the oil from reaching the shore and causing damage. But, the use of dispersants comes with risks. Some scientists fear that the chemicals can harm marine life and have long-term effects on the ecosystem. 

In response to public concerns, BP, the company responsible for the oil rig, announced that they will stop using dispersants from the air and focus on using them only at the source of the spill.

story: There may be no greater entertainer in the history
text:
There may be no greater entertainer in the history of show business than Charlie Chaplin. He was a brilliant actor, director, and composer who captivated audiences with his silent movies. His unique mix of comedy, drama, and social commentary brought joy and inspiration to people all around the world. 

Chaplin was born on April 16, 1889, in London, England. Growing up, he faced many hardships. His childhood was filled with poverty and neglect. Yet, he managed to find solace in the world of theater. He spent hours watching plays and practicing his acting skills. 

Eventually, Charlie found work as a circus performer and a vaudeville comedian. But his big break came in 1913 when he was hired by the Keystone Film Company. It was there that he created his most famous character: the Tramp. The Tramp was a hobo with a bowler hat, cane, and a funny walk. 

Chaplin's movies were a huge success. They made him a wealthy and famous man. But fame did not change him. He continued to work hard and create masterpieces, such as "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "City Lights."

story: Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans
text:
Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans in history. He was born on January 15, 1929. Martin was a civil rights leader from Georgia. He became a minister and a spokesman for equality and civil rights for African Americans. 

Martin Luther King Jr.' s most famous speech was "I Have a Dream." He gave this speech on August 28, 1963 in Washington D. C. There were many people there. They wanted civil rights too. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke about equality and freedom. He wanted an end to racism and discrimination. 

Martin Luther King Jr. believed that people should be judged by the content of their character and not by the color of their skin. He worked hard to make this a reality. He organized peaceful protests and spoke out against segregation. Martin Luther King Jr.' s work made a big difference. In 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act. This law ended segregation in schools, workplaces, and public places. 

Martin Luther King Jr. was a brave man. He believed in peace and nonviolence.

story: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions.
text:
The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions. Film crews from all around the world come to shoot their movies here. The landscape is magical, with its vast red dunes and beautiful mountains. The sun sets and rises over the Atlas Mountains, creating a breathtaking view. 

People in Ouarzazate are very friendly and welcoming to visitors. They love to share their culture and traditions. The local markets are full of colorful spices, fruits, and handmade crafts. Visitors can try traditional Moroccan dishes like tagine and couscous. 

But it's not only about tourism. Ouarzazate is also an important economic center. Many people work in the agriculture industry, growing fruits, vegetables, and olives. Others work in industries like ceramics and rug-making. The city is also home to a large solar power plant, which provides electricity to the region. 

Living in Ouarzazate is different from living in big cities. Life is more simple and slower-paced. People live in traditional mud-brick houses called kasbahs.

story: Chemical dispersants keep flowing into the Gulf of
text:
Chemical dispersants keep flowing into the Gulf of Mexico. Oil spills create huge problems for marine life. Fish, turtles, and birds can die when their habitats are contaminated. Dispersants can make things worse. They help to break up big oil slicks, but they also hurt animals. Some dispersants kill zooplankton. This is food for small fish. Without enough zooplankton, the food chain can collapse. 

People are trying to stop the spills with booms and skimmers. Booms are barriers that float on the water. They trap oil droplets before they reach coastlines. Skimmers remove oil from the surface. They leave clean water behind. 

Cleanup teams are working around the clock. They collect oil-soaked birds and wash them clean. They rescue injured animals, like turtles, and take them to rehabilitation centres. They clean beaches and marshes. But the damage to wildlife may not be reversible. 

People are sad about the oil spill. They want to help. They make donations for the cleanup effort. They volunteer to help clean up the beaches and marshes.
